⸺ HIP-ARCHIVE-2 ⸺ / hip-76-linear-lockup-curve
HIP 76: Simplify Lockup and veTokens https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md
Siegfried 02/14/2023 1:12 PM
1
valerie 02/14/2023 1:12 PM
HIP 76: Simplify Lockup and veTokens Author(s): @ferebee Start Date: 2023-02-14 Category: Economic Original HIP PR: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/547 Tracking Issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/560 Summary HIP-51 specifies that holders of HNT may lock their HNT for up to 48 months in order to receive veHNT (vote-escrowed HNT). veHNT conveys voting power in the Helium DAO and may be delegated to a subDAO. The combination of HNT locked for a duration, together with the assigned veHNT, is called a position. One wallet may contain multiple positions. With this HIP, we propose simplifying the relationship between lockup duration and the associated amount of veHNT, eliminating the minimum lockup period, introducing a 1 HNT minimum per lockup position, and clarifying certain rules relating to the “landrush” bonus. Motivation The current model of veHNT lockup does not ideally support long-term incentives. To encourage as many participants as possible to lock their HNT and participate in governance, the relationship between the lockup period and the resulting veHNT multiplier should be simple and easy to understand. The more flexible and convenient the lockup procedure can be made, the more approachable it will become. Changing the lockup curve to a simple linear function, which is easier to understand, removes these counterintuitive edge cases. Implementation becomes significantly simpler, quicker, and safer. In summary, the motivation of this HIP is to improve governance usability and long-term engagement and to provide clarity on the rules governing landrush. Rendered View https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md

Siegfried 02/14/2023 1:39 PM
Very minor remarks: - The HIP is actually relevant for all holders of HNT, MOBILE and IOT - even for the ones that have not yet decided to lock-up tokens, because (1) changing lock-up curve and (2) eliminating minimum lock-up duration is relevant for everyone. Because in all likelihood it will give reason to any holder to think again whether, how many and for how long they want to lock-up tokens.

Siegfried
Very minor remarks: - The HIP is actually relevant for all holders of HNT, MOBILE and IOT - even for the ones that have not yet decided to lock-up tokens, because (1) changing lock-up curve and (2) eliminating minimum lock-up duration is relevant for everyone. Because in all likelihood it will give reason to any holder to think again whether, how many and for how long they want to lock-up tokens.
ferebee 02/14/2023 3:05 PM
I think that’s stretching it... everything is ultimately relevant to eveyone.
Another_AKA
How do I interpret this? Will I be able to move a lock veHNT position to a different wallet?
ferebee 02/14/2023 3:07 PM
Sorry, no. Re-delegate between subDAOs.

waveform 02/14/2023 3:43 PM
"The duration of the landrush multiplier is counted from the moment of L1 transition" I think should be "The duration of the landrush multiplier is counted from the moment of L1 transition, or the most recent extension or lock-up within the 7 day landrush". I need to double check this but I think that if a validator extends their position on day 7 of the landrush to 6months+1day then they get 6months plus 6 days of 3x . Its 6 days as its Landrush days 1-6, as they dont earn on the 7th day of landrush as they need to undelegate to extend and then redelegate, and there are no earnings when undelegated.
EdB-charlietango
Are we supposed to use terms like a certain number of blocks instead of days?
waveform 02/14/2023 3:44 PM
An epoch is 24 hours, so we count days.

KeithR 02/14/2023 10:01 PM
Well done. I am in. I am fairly certain I know the answer, but I just want to verify... If I put up a portion of my bag for 1461 epochs during the land rush period. I get a 3x multiplier. I immediately put it into cool-down. I do NOT lose my 3x multiplier; right? It all just starts to decay incrementally every epoch; as one would expect.
1
KeithR
Well done. I am in. I am fairly certain I know the answer, but I just want to verify... If I put up a portion of my bag for 1461 epochs during the land rush period. I get a 3x multiplier. I immediately put it into cool-down. I do NOT lose my 3x multiplier; right? It all just starts to decay incrementally every epoch; as one would expect.
waveform 02/15/2023 1:27 AM
Yup, restating something ive said before. The cooldown decay and the 3x multiplier are two separate things. The veHNT number can be stable or varying. But the 3x multiplier is either on or off, and its timer starts ticking the moment of the most recent staking change in the 7 day cooldown period.
KeithR 02/15/2023 1:53 AM
Excellent. Now to figure out the staking delegations for each rung of my ladder. I put my odds at about 60% I will regret laddering my stake rather than putting it all on 1461 epochs and at about 5% I will be patting myself on my back so hard I will sprain my arm.

waveform
"The duration of the landrush multiplier is counted from the moment of L1 transition" I think should be "The duration of the landrush multiplier is counted from the moment of L1 transition, or the most recent extension or lock-up within the 7 day landrush". I need to double check this but I think that if a validator extends their position on day 7 of the landrush to 6months+1day then they get 6months plus 6 days of 3x . Its 6 days as its Landrush days 1-6, as they dont earn on the 7th day of landrush as they need to undelegate to extend and then redelegate, and there are no earnings when undelegated.

ferebee 02/15/2023 3:20 AM

2
AndrewsMD
Excellent work @ferebee. I might have missed it. Did we specify that veHNT remains non transferrable for clarity purposes?
ferebee 02/15/2023 3:25 AM
HIP-51 is adamant that veHNT is fully non-transferable… There had been discussions here earlier whether it might be possible to make lockup positions transferable after all, but that raises legal issues, so I consider it out of scope for this proposal and am not mentioning it in the interest of simplicity.
3
ferebee
I consider that an implementation detail and am purposefully not getting into questions like how Solana treats leap seconds. (edited)

gtelnet 02/15/2023 7:57 AM
Great work on this @ferebee. Very clear and concise! Question that is somewhat related to this - when a validator is presented with the option of extending their lockup during the landrush period, can they choose to extend the duration of only a portion of their HNT? Or is it an all or nothing extension of the full 10K HNT? i.e. can we extend 1K HNT for 48 months and leave the remaining 9K at the mandatory 6 months?
gtelnet
Great work on this @ferebee. Very clear and concise! Question that is somewhat related to this - when a validator is presented with the option of extending their lockup during the landrush period, can they choose to extend the duration of only a portion of their HNT? Or is it an all or nothing extension of the full 10K HNT? i.e. can we extend 1K HNT for 48 months and leave the remaining 9K at the mandatory 6 months?
ferebee 02/15/2023 8:11 AM
A wallet with a validator that rolls over into HNT lockup is assigned a single position of 10,000 HNT locked to 6 months. (Or multiples of 10,000 HNT if there were more validators in the wallet. Or does that result in multiple positions with 10,000 each? Implementation detail, doesn’t actually matter.) That landrush lockup positon is no different from any other position created during landrush. So, the provisions from the section “Landrush 3x Multiplier apply, specifically The landrush position may be split into multiple landrush positions, which may be extended or delegated separately. As stated in the next section, after the landrush ends, you can still split the position, but the 3x multiplier stays with the original position, and the new position does not inherit the 3x multiplier.
1
gtelnet 02/15/2023 8:14 AM
Perfect! thank you!
ferebee 02/15/2023 8:19 AM
BTW everybody should think about this, not just validator operators. Let’s say you have 1,000 HNT and lock it all for 48 months during the landrush. Initially, the lockup is automatically perpetual, i. e., it automatically keeps extending itself again to 48 months. A year later, you decide you want to cool down 500 HNT. If you had everything in one position, you have to split the position, so one position keeps its 500 HNT times 100x veHNT multiplier for 48-month lockup times 3x landrush bonus, or 150,000 veHNT. The second position loses the landrush bonus, so it immediately drops from 150,000 veHNT to 50,000 veHNT, and then cools down linearly over 48 months from there. By contrast, if you split the 1,000 HNT lockup position into two during the initial 7-day landrush period, they each independently get the 3x multiplier. Then, you can enter one into cooldown a year later, and it will keep its 3x multiplier, and cool down from 150,000 veHNT. In any case, though, the 3x multiplier goes away for all positions 48 months after the initial lockup during the landrush. (Yes, it’s a bit complicated. ️)
1
1

ferebee
BTW everybody should think about this, not just validator operators. Let’s say you have 1,000 HNT and lock it all for 48 months during the landrush. Initially, the lockup is automatically perpetual, i. e., it automatically keeps extending itself again to 48 months. A year later, you decide you want to cool down 500 HNT. If you had everything in one position, you have to split the position, so one position keeps its 500 HNT times 100x veHNT multiplier for 48-month lockup times 3x landrush bonus, or 150,000 veHNT. The second position loses the landrush bonus, so it immediately drops from 150,000 veHNT to 50,000 veHNT, and then cools down linearly over 48 months from there. By contrast, if you split the 1,000 HNT lockup position into two during the initial 7-day landrush period, they each independently get the 3x multiplier. Then, you can enter one into cooldown a year later, and it will keep its 3x multiplier, and cool down from 150,000 veHNT. In any case, though, the 3x multiplier goes away for all positions 48 months after the initial lockup during the landrush. (Yes, it’s a bit complicated. ️)
waveform 02/15/2023 11:53 AM
Yeah I can see people with large positions (eg validator owners) splitting their initial positions into several smaller chunks to be more granular in their staking periods, constant lockup vs cooldown or delegation. This gives them extra flexibility for future changes without losing any 3x multiplier.

waveform 02/15/2023 12:02 PM
Quick response on that first part. If you have multiple validators on one wallet you get one big position of veHNT
ferebee
BTW everybody should think about this, not just validator operators. Let’s say you have 1,000 HNT and lock it all for 48 months during the landrush. Initially, the lockup is automatically perpetual, i. e., it automatically keeps extending itself again to 48 months. A year later, you decide you want to cool down 500 HNT. If you had everything in one position, you have to split the position, so one position keeps its 500 HNT times 100x veHNT multiplier for 48-month lockup times 3x landrush bonus, or 150,000 veHNT. The second position loses the landrush bonus, so it immediately drops from 150,000 veHNT to 50,000 veHNT, and then cools down linearly over 48 months from there. By contrast, if you split the 1,000 HNT lockup position into two during the initial 7-day landrush period, they each independently get the 3x multiplier. Then, you can enter one into cooldown a year later, and it will keep its 3x multiplier, and cool down from 150,000 veHNT. In any case, though, the 3x multiplier goes away for all positions 48 months after the initial lockup during the landrush. (Yes, it’s a bit complicated. ️)
KeithR 02/15/2023 1:45 PM
Am I correct that this concept also applies if you intend to split your veHNT across all three subDAOs (lets assume the HWiFi one exists six months from now) evenly (lets assume 33.3% to each) AND you want the land rush on that last third stake that you should put two separate 33% positions onto one subDAO during land rush and then move one of them instead of expecting to split a 66.6% stake on one subDAO into two later? [hope that run-on sentence was clear enough] (edited)
13:47
Because splitting the 66.6% stake into two and moving one to the new subDAO would cause it to lose the land rush bonus but just moving one of the two 33.3% stakes from subDAO #2 to subDAO #3 would not lose the land rush bonus. Correct? (edited)
KeithR

Siegfried 02/15/2023 1:51 PM
Is congruent with what I understood so far. (1. You can only delegate whole positions to a subDAO (all the veHNT I get from amount x HNT locked must be delegated to one subDAO) 2. If you split a position with 3x multiplier after the 7 days, you lose the multiplier on all new resulting positions. One position appears to stay the "original" position, but with reduced HNT, that one doesn't lose the multiplier) (edited)
KeithR
Because splitting the 66.6% stake into two and moving one to the new subDAO would cause it to lose the land rush bonus but just moving one of the two 33.3% stakes from subDAO #2 to subDAO #3 would not lose the land rush bonus. Correct? (edited)
waveform 02/15/2023 1:55 PM
You should have 3 positions, delegate 1 to subDAO A, 1 to subDAO B and the 3rd can be to either or undelegated. When 3rd subDAO turns up undelegate position 3 (if you need to) and redelegate to new subDAO
waveform
You should have 3 positions, delegate 1 to subDAO A, 1 to subDAO B and the 3rd can be to either or undelegated. When 3rd subDAO turns up undelegate position 3 (if you need to) and redelegate to new subDAO
KeithR 02/15/2023 1:56 PM
Adding new column to my excel spreadsheet outlining my veHNT staking ladder!
ferebee 02/15/2023 2:12 PM
All correct. Basically you may want to anticipate all possible different configurations of positions you could want to have during your initial lockup duration (up to 48 months) and create a position for each. Configurations include staking to different subDAOs (there might be more), and also whether a position enters cooldown or not. After the initial lockup period, the 3x landrush multiplier goes away, so then you can split positions however you like with no penalty. The only disadvantage to having a larger number of lockup positions is that it’s inconvenient and more work to keep track of.
waveform
You should have 3 positions, delegate 1 to subDAO A, 1 to subDAO B and the 3rd can be to either or undelegated. When 3rd subDAO turns up undelegate position 3 (if you need to) and redelegate to new subDAO
KeithR 02/15/2023 10:36 PM
I am currently planning for a total of 9 positions at the beginning; 3 levels delegation by subDAO and 3 levels of delegation by redemption date. Every 6 months I will create a new position with any new holdings at the max redemption date I am comfortable with at the time (assuming 1461 epochs). All positions will be put into cool-down immediately. Anyone have reason to believe this is a stupid strategy?
KeithR

All positions will be put into cool-down immediately. Anyone have reason to believe this is a stupid strategy?

KeithR 02/16/2023 2:00 AM
Which one do you think? "general" seems the only one where it applies but this would be a way more complex topic than most of the discussions there. Governance-related channels maybe but certainly not a perfect match. Certainly appropriate on the CryptoTraders server if the focus was on the token earnings. I do want to focus on the actual strategy of managing the lockup, moving the positions once a third subDAO comes online, etc. For instance I could see someone suggesting even smaller positions for even more control options and being able to be more reactive. Or maybe some strategies about deciding the various delegations by redemption date; every 3 months instead of heavily leaning towards the later 6 month periods. The implications of this HIP if you will.

ferebee 02/16/2023 2:23 AM

ferebee 02/16/2023 2:24 AM

KeithR
If I stake for 1461 epochs I get 1000x veHNT; right? So if I stake for 730 epochs do I get 500x? (edited)
ferebee 02/16/2023 2:25 AM
Oh, yes, but you get 100x veHNT. Not 1000x.
ferebee
“Spamming the chain”, BTW, in the context of the 1 HNT position minimum, was a concern Noah had. I’m not qualified to have an opinion.
groot 02/16/2023 2:25 AM
1HNT minimum is valid, otherwise you could make them 1 bone (1e-8 HNT). (edit: there is actually a proposal on Solana to make a 1 SOL min mandatory iirc) (edited)
1
KeithR
If I stake for 1461 epochs I get 1000x veHNT; right? So if I stake for 730 epochs do I get 500x? (edited)
ferebee 02/16/2023 2:31 AM
And the veHNT is a simple linear function of the lockup duration, yes, as shown in the graph in the HIP. One could consider it a step function, but IMO it’s simpler to think of it as a linear function where the input value (d = number of days) is clipped to an integer. The implementation calculates veHNT with a granularity of 1 day. So it’s just veHNT(d) = d * 100 / 1461
1
KeithR 02/16/2023 2:38 AM
Because I love doing stupid excel math... If you staked 1461 HNT for 1461 epochs during the land rush period you would have 438,300 veHNT of voting power. If you staked 1 HNT for each and every epoch of the 1461 possible epochs during the land rush period you would have 219,302 veHNT of voting power. Half of the voting power, but every day you get to have 1 of your HNT back!
KeithR
Because I love doing stupid excel math... If you staked 1461 HNT for 1461 epochs during the land rush period you would have 438,300 veHNT of voting power. If you staked 1 HNT for each and every epoch of the 1461 possible epochs during the land rush period you would have 219,302 veHNT of voting power. Half of the voting power, but every day you get to have 1 of your HNT back!
ferebee 02/16/2023 2:48 AM
I suspect the benefit of laddering strategies might be overrated. For example, if you lock half your HNT permanently at 48 months and leave the other half unlocked, you also have half the maximum voting power, but you have full optionality with the other half from day one. If you don’t enter cooldown on the half that is locked, you can maintain the 3x landrush multiplier on the entire position for 48 months. If you intend to gain additional HNT over time and create new lockup positions with that, none of it will gain the 3x multiplier. I haven’t done any modeling, and am not smart enough to model it in my head, but my guess is that the 3x multiplier was chosen so it’s in your best interest to lock as much HNT right from the start to maximize voting power.
Siegfried 02/16/2023 3:14 AM
Regarding these "how many positions should I start out with to have enough flexibility for cooldown/delegation"-questions: My preferred UI option would have been: you lock up a certain amount of HNT and get a certain amount of veHNT (that decays at a certain rate after cooldown initiaton). And then you can decide x% of that will be delegated to subDAO a, y% delegated to subDAO b. And you can freely change x and y every epoch, as long as x+y<=100%. If I understood correctly, the main reason for this inflexible "we need to decide on percentages before we lock up HNT and then have to use the percentages that these positions provide as delegation Legos" procedure is for ease of implementation, right? Wondering if moving to a unified veHNT "payout" and decay function would allow for such a UI now. (edited)
gateholder 02/16/2023 4:25 AM
I can say I have read the the whole VEHNT (I am going to call in "vent" when I say it out loud) I still don't understand it, because just having voting power doesn't provide much incentive to "stake"
Siegfried
Regarding these "how many positions should I start out with to have enough flexibility for cooldown/delegation"-questions: My preferred UI option would have been: you lock up a certain amount of HNT and get a certain amount of veHNT (that decays at a certain rate after cooldown initiaton). And then you can decide x% of that will be delegated to subDAO a, y% delegated to subDAO b. And you can freely change x and y every epoch, as long as x+y<=100%. If I understood correctly, the main reason for this inflexible "we need to decide on percentages before we lock up HNT and then have to use the percentages that these positions provide as delegation Legos" procedure is for ease of implementation, right? Wondering if moving to a unified veHNT "payout" and decay function would allow for such a UI now. (edited)
ferebee 02/16/2023 4:29 AM
Not being a blockchain developer (anecdote: blockchain developers seem to talk a lot about “chewing glass”) I can only speculate, but the main reason we’re talking about creating positions in advance is that positions can’t be split after landrush without losing the 3x multiplier on the new position. Aside from that, your proposed UI is basically just a perfectly reasonable way to represent how positions are created, split, delegated and redelegated. The rules that apply to the 3x landrush multiplier, combined with the ability to extend lockup on landrush positions, initiate cooldown, etc., without losing the multiplier, are difficulty to represent without the concept of “positions” or some similar concept. I suspect.
1

Aside from that, your proposed UI is basically just a perfectly reasonable way to represent how positions are created, split, delegated and redelegated. The rules that apply to the 3x landrush multiplier, combined with the ability to extend lockup on landrush positions, initiate cooldown, etc., without losing the multiplier, are difficulty to represent without the concept of “positions” or some similar concept. I suspect.

Siegfried 02/16/2023 4:43 AM
You not only get voting power, but also get token rewards for delegating veHNT. You get some MOBILE tokens when delegating veHNT to the Mobile subDAO, you get IOT tokens when delegating veHNT to the IOT subDAO. For some, that is the most important incentive to "stake".

gateholder 02/16/2023 5:02 AM

Siegfried
Regarding these "how many positions should I start out with to have enough flexibility for cooldown/delegation"-questions: My preferred UI option would have been: you lock up a certain amount of HNT and get a certain amount of veHNT (that decays at a certain rate after cooldown initiaton). And then you can decide x% of that will be delegated to subDAO a, y% delegated to subDAO b. And you can freely change x and y every epoch, as long as x+y<=100%. If I understood correctly, the main reason for this inflexible "we need to decide on percentages before we lock up HNT and then have to use the percentages that these positions provide as delegation Legos" procedure is for ease of implementation, right? Wondering if moving to a unified veHNT "payout" and decay function would allow for such a UI now. (edited)
waveform 02/16/2023 5:02 AM
Using the current programmed design: One of 4 things to remember is that to change anything about your position once it is delegated you have to undelegate, take the action on the position and redelegate. The 2nd is that you do not receive subDAO token emissions in an epoch (24 hour on Solana) where you are undelegated for any amount of time. The 3rd is that there is no "split" option. A split is a partial transfer out to a new position. The final one is that actions on a position are all or nothing. (Excluding a transfer out obviously) Some of these would need to change to do what you desire. (edited)
1
gateholder
wait am I missing that in hip 51?
waveform 02/16/2023 5:04 AM
We aint waiting ... full steam ahead. On Helium - you stake 10K HNT and receive HNT On Solana - you stake >1 HNT, and then delegate to MOBILE or IOT and then receive MOBILE or IOT as appropriate. Staking will no longer return HNT.
waveform
We aint waiting ... full steam ahead. On Helium - you stake 10K HNT and receive HNT On Solana - you stake >1 HNT, and then delegate to MOBILE or IOT and then receive MOBILE or IOT as appropriate. Staking will no longer return HNT.

waveform 02/16/2023 6:13 AM
If you delegate 100 HNT for 48 (100x) months with the 3x multiplier you would have 30,000 veHNT which is your voting power If you delegate that to MOBILE and the total pool of veHNT delegated to MOBILE was 300,000 then you would have 10% of the staked+delegated MOBILE pool And that would get you 10% of of the 6% of MOBILE assigned to Stakers in MOBILE in that Epoch. HIP75 says 30B MOBILE per year = 82.2M per day So you would get 10% of 6% of 82.2M = 493K MOBILE per day This is for the 2023-2024 year. 2022-2023 would be different as its not a full year. Please anyone check my math.
2

gateholder 02/16/2023 8:48 AM

2
gateholder
also is the rewards being paid into the wallet address? or is it being held to the end of the staking period?
ferebee 02/16/2023 10:35 AM
[… It looks like I posted an incorrect answer here previously concerning the payout of delegation rewards. I’ve deleted it.] PoC and data transfer rewards are not paid out until claimed. They will be computed by the off-chain oracles, and can then be “claimed” by the wallet holding the hotspot. Computing and maintaining these (many, small) rewards off-chain initially, and batching the payout process, reduces the on-chain workload and makes the process more efficient, reducing transaction costs as the network scales. (edited)
Another_AKA
But I'm still coming up if 1,479/day. .003 x .06 x 82,200,000 = 1,479

ferebee
[… It looks like I posted an incorrect answer here previously concerning the payout of delegation rewards. I’ve deleted it.] PoC and data transfer rewards are not paid out until claimed. They will be computed by the off-chain oracles, and can then be “claimed” by the wallet holding the hotspot. Computing and maintaining these (many, small) rewards off-chain initially, and batching the payout process, reduces the on-chain workload and makes the process more efficient, reducing transaction costs as the network scales. (edited)
Siegfried 02/16/2023 1:07 PM
So this also changed? I had asked this a while ago and had explicitly been answered that subDAO delegation rewards are (finally) paid out only after being explicitly claimed: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1014268264018354247/1049338627290841179 (edited)
13:09
Reason was, that for reducing accounting burden, I very strongly prefer rewards not being paid out daily, but only after being claimed:

Another_AKA 02/16/2023 2:48 PM
6% of 82,200,00 is 4,932,000 not 493,000. That is how interpreted 493K and came up with 1,479/day, With 6% of 82,200,200 = 4,932,000 x .003 = 14,796 Mobile/day.
14:50

14:50
again.
Siegfried
Actually, I want to be able to claim them just once at the end of each year, to keep my accounting burden as low as possible. (edited)
AndrewsMD 02/16/2023 7:21 PM
I wonder if this approach could potentially cause a higher tax burden. For example. If the value of HNT raises from X to Y over the course of 12 months such that the price surged in the last quarter, claiming all earned subDAO tokens in month 12 at the rate of Y at month 12 might cause the tax burden to be greater than if they were claimed at a lower average or less than average valuation throughout the year. It’s just something to ponder. Of course the converse is true if X is greater than Y over the course of a year.
1
ferebee 02/17/2023 12:10 AM
Claiming the tokens,say, quarterly, should mitigate most of that if it’s a concern, still keep accounting simple, and you have the tokens available sooner for subDAO governance. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

ferebee 02/17/2023 7:16 AM
I read both of those, and understood them to refer to rewards paid to “rewardable entities”, i. e., hotspots, which receive rewards computed by offchain oracles. It doesn’t say that veHNT delegations are rewardable entities, so it’s not clear to me that this would apply to them as well. I thought, perhaps for no good reason, that veHNT delegation rewards would be computed by a smart contract on the blockchain, in connection with the HNT lockup, and not by offchain oracles.
ferebee
I read both of those, and understood them to refer to rewards paid to “rewardable entities”, i. e., hotspots, which receive rewards computed by offchain oracles. It doesn’t say that veHNT delegations are rewardable entities, so it’s not clear to me that this would apply to them as well. I thought, perhaps for no good reason, that veHNT delegation rewards would be computed by a smart contract on the blockchain, in connection with the HNT lockup, and not by offchain oracles.
waveform 02/17/2023 7:19 AM
Im going with "Following the transition to Solana, all actors in the network that receive tokens are considered "Rewardable Entities."
waveform
Im going with "Following the transition to Solana, all actors in the network that receive tokens are considered "Rewardable Entities."

AndrewsMD 02/20/2023 11:23 AM
Seems reasonable. The fine details appears to be well flushed out over the past few weeks. If no major dissension after the community call, . . . let’s vote and help expedite the Solana migration. Noah owes Ferebee beer and wine if this goes through
waveform 02/20/2023 11:41 AM
Has there yet been any opposition or challenges to this HIP?
waveform
Has there yet been any opposition or challenges to this HIP?
ferebee 02/20/2023 11:55 AM
Really, no. The first go around, @Tushar questioned whether we would be sufficiently protected against whales swooping in to dominate a vote with short-term locked HNT, considering the combined effects of removing the 6-month minimum and the linear lockup curve, which increases the veHNT given to short-term lockups. But after a few back-of-the-envelope calculations, I think he was satisfied. There were also concerns around the proposal to make veHNT transferable, as had been suggested, but we’ve nixed that anyway and are keeping veHNT “fully non-transferable” as specified by HIP-51. I think everything else is quite non-controversial.
waveform
Has there yet been any opposition or challenges to this HIP?
multiverse_Elmo 02/20/2023 12:04 PM
I really didn't like the red color on the graph...kinda made me angry. Otherwise Ferebee did a superb job.

ferebee 02/20/2023 12:14 PM
If your HNT wallet has been slumming, it might make sense to transfer all your HNT to a fresh wallet right before or after the L1 transition.
12:17
If you still have a staked validator, and your validator HNT wallet has been really slumming, you might even want to consider transferring your stake to a fresh validator and wallet. (You can “sell” a validator stake to a new wallet if it’s also transferred to a new validator. So your friendly staking provider would need to spin up a new validator for you, if that’s what you need to do.)
AndrewsMD 02/20/2023 5:05 PM

ferebee 02/22/2023 8:19 AM
I’m ready to give an intro to HIP-76 on the Helium Community Call starting now in 45 minutes, if time permits.
ferebee 02/22/2023 8:27 AM
For reference, the current version of the HIP is published at https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md Valerie merged all the corrections and edits I’ve collected from this discussion so far as of yesterday. Thanks everybody for your input. Special thanks to @Siegfried for proofreading everything multiple times like a hawk. Extra-special thanks to @valerie for being generally HIP and @waveform for tracking down bits of information even when it was like pulling dragon’s teeth, and super-special thanks to @n_ for heading the programming effort that will make veHNT a reality in the first place and lead us to the promised land of Solana.
HIP/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md at main · helium/HIP
Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.
1
1
Siegfried 02/22/2023 9:05 AM
I have a cosmetic suggestion, that might improve readability of the HIP and doesn't delay voting on the hip if not accepted. Regarding the structure, the HIP looks like this (just showing headlines): (edited)
09:05
"Minimum Lockup Amount" and "Landrush 3x multiplier" aren't things that are different than "Detailed Explanation".
09:08
In fact, they should be subsections of "Detailed explanation". Ideally, the structure of "Detailed explanation" should reflect the structure of "Summary" As in the first part of Detailed Explanation "Simplify lockup" and "eliminate minimum period" are not clearly separate, I suggest the following structure:
09:08
It is essentially just moving headlines/subsection titles. (edited)
09:09
@ferebee Small last minute suggestion

Max - Just Max 02/22/2023 10:17 AM

Max - Just Max

Siegfried 02/22/2023 10:18 AM
10:18
Hip 52
Max - Just Max 02/22/2023 10:18 AM
Right, and what does HIP-51 say?
Siegfried 02/22/2023 10:19 AM
10:19
Hip 53
ferebee 02/22/2023 10:19 AM
True, HIP-52:
10:19
A user’s veIOT lockup power is determined by 1) the amount of IOT they lock up with, and 2) the amount of time they commit to locking up their IOT. The structure applies a linear multiplier of time to the amount of HNT locked up in the voting contract. For the maximum period of four years, users receive 100x the veIOT. For the minimum period of six months, users receive 1x the veIOT. Note that veIOT is non-transferable, and represented as a non-fungible coupon in the user’s IOT address.

ferebee 02/22/2023 11:14 AM
I think I’ve stated my position as best I can: IOT and MOBILE subDAOs currently do not exist, as they do not have governance, as veIOT and veMOBILE currently do not exist. I respect your position that there needs to be a clear delineation between Helium DAO governance and subDAO governance, and fully agree. But IMO any argument that a subDAO is being overridden by a HIP at this time, in particular before the L1 transition, is erroneous, as subDAO governance can only be overridden if it exists, which it doesn’t. So I respectfully decline your suggestion to remove the provisions on the lockup curve of IOT and MOBILE. If others want to argue for their removal as well, I’ll revisit my position.

ferebee 02/22/2023 2:51 PM
Well... The discussion refers to this, which is in the “Summary” section: The mechanics described here in terms of HNT and veHNT will apply equally to veMOBILE and veIOT when they are introduced. As HIPs 51–53 and HIP-70 do not specify a 3x landrush period for IOT and MOBILE, the landrush provisions will only apply to a subDAO token if the subDAO introduces its own landrush period for its veToken.
14:52
(Why under Summary? That’s a good question.)
Siegfried 02/22/2023 2:53 PM

ferebee
Well... The discussion refers to this, which is in the “Summary” section: The mechanics described here in terms of HNT and veHNT will apply equally to veMOBILE and veIOT when they are introduced. As HIPs 51–53 and HIP-70 do not specify a 3x landrush period for IOT and MOBILE, the landrush provisions will only apply to a subDAO token if the subDAO introduces its own landrush period for its veToken.

ferebee 02/22/2023 3:01 PM
IMO Max’ concern is valid, and I agree that the Helium DAO should not preempt what is properly subDAO governance. Where we disagree is the question of whether subDAO governance that could be preempted and should be protected from preemption currently exists (Max’ view), or whether we are still finalizing the construction of the subDAO’s (my view). I’m open to further input on this, though I do suspect Max and I have each said our piece.

n_ 02/22/2023 3:53 PM
As the dev who has to implement this, adding a point here. Having MOBILE and IOT on a different curve than HNT is a huge lift. Bigger than having HNT on the original curve. We have to implement everything to do the old curve PLUS an extra set of statements to dodge the old curve for HNT only.
gateholder
both points of view have merit while I mostly agree with @ferebee, @Max - Just Max has points I guess I am confused why we can't get to common ground with either leaving out the contentious points? does that break the HIP?
ferebee 02/22/2023 3:53 PM
We can take out the veDNT linearization proviso without any damage to the rest of the HIP. I’m strongly in favor of keeping it in, partly because (as I recall) it was put there on Noah’s request in the first place, and one intent of this HIP is to help him do a better/quicker/safer job. And partly because Max’ approach of taking it out and fixing that later may introduce issues of its own, such as, how can the subDAOs make changes with proper governance concerning the distribution of veDNT, when their governance as specified requires that veDNT already be distributed. Either way, there are issues with philosophically perfect governance, from some points of view.
n_
As the dev who has to implement this, adding a point here. Having MOBILE and IOT on a different curve than HNT is a huge lift. Bigger than having HNT on the original curve. We have to implement everything to do the old curve PLUS an extra set of statements to dodge the old curve for HNT only.

One edit is pending that merely changes the subhead Detailed Explanation to read Simplified Lockup Curve instead based on feedback from Siegfried. No substantive change. I expect Valerie will merge that shortly. (edited)

ferebee 02/24/2023 12:21 AM

n_
As the dev who has to implement this, adding a point here. Having MOBILE and IOT on a different curve than HNT is a huge lift. Bigger than having HNT on the original curve. We have to implement everything to do the old curve PLUS an extra set of statements to dodge the old curve for HNT only.
Tushar 02/24/2023 10:56 AM
Agreed, we should keep everything on the same curve imo
Tushar
Agreed, we should keep everything on the same curve imo
Max - Just Max 02/24/2023 11:14 AM
I think that's fine as an end result but wasn't the whole point of multiple tokens so that each subDAO could decide how to govern themselves? A blanket HIP changing all subDAOs is the antithesis of that and makes me further question why I'd want any DNTs.
Max - Just Max
I think that's fine as an end result but wasn't the whole point of multiple tokens so that each subDAO could decide how to govern themselves? A blanket HIP changing all subDAOs is the antithesis of that and makes me further question why I'd want any DNTs.
KeithR 02/24/2023 1:41 PM
Good question Max. But 'governing themselves' is allowing each DNT to vote on their own Improvement Plans. Establishing a decay curve (or straight line) as a mechanism for calculating vote power and rewards doesn't seem too offensive. The over reach in this case is only about a mechanism for counting rather than forcing governance. Every state in our union is required to have a straight line decay curve between $100 and $0 and they have to use the very same dollars; but they can govern themselves with their own taxes and fees for using highways (which also have federal requirements of speed and usage and design).
13:42
I do appreciate how hard you are pushing for strong independent statehood though.

Max - Just Max 02/26/2023 9:08 AM

hashc0de 02/27/2023 12:35 PM
Before this HIP goes to vote, I'd propose one more change if @ferebee and others agree. Change minimum stake period to 1 month after veHNT is live on Solana. Specifically, it addresses a few gaps. Today, all existing staked validators would transition over to a "minimum stake period" when moved to veHNT Solana. HIP 76 sort of makes this minimum 0 days because the curve goes all the way down to 0 days. It also mentions 6 months explicitly but I'd like this to be way more clear. For those who were expecting a 3 month cooldown (125k blocks) this bumps it up to 6 months right at the transition. Now that I look back on this, I wonder if this was fair. Alternatively making it a 1 day or 1 week period encourages the wrong incentives. So I think it should be higher. I think 1 month is a happy medium. It also helps that we're about a month away from the migration so if we started voting today, they can still choose to enter cooldown (if they choose to) fairly quickly after the migration completes. Also the land rush period allows anyone to extend it longer if they choose. Putting all these decisions in the near term seem better than having to make one choice today (HIP 76 voting), one more choice at migration (land rush or not), one choice sometime in the interim (what subdao to delegate to), and then again another choice in 6 months. Just decide on HIP 76 now and make one more decision right after the migration when all the attention is on it.
12:35
Curious on thoughts.
hashc0de
Before this HIP goes to vote, I'd propose one more change if @ferebee and others agree. Change minimum stake period to 1 month after veHNT is live on Solana. Specifically, it addresses a few gaps. Today, all existing staked validators would transition over to a "minimum stake period" when moved to veHNT Solana. HIP 76 sort of makes this minimum 0 days because the curve goes all the way down to 0 days. It also mentions 6 months explicitly but I'd like this to be way more clear. For those who were expecting a 3 month cooldown (125k blocks) this bumps it up to 6 months right at the transition. Now that I look back on this, I wonder if this was fair. Alternatively making it a 1 day or 1 week period encourages the wrong incentives. So I think it should be higher. I think 1 month is a happy medium. It also helps that we're about a month away from the migration so if we started voting today, they can still choose to enter cooldown (if they choose to) fairly quickly after the migration completes. Also the land rush period allows anyone to extend it longer if they choose. Putting all these decisions in the near term seem better than having to make one choice today (HIP 76 voting), one more choice at migration (land rush or not), one choice sometime in the interim (what subdao to delegate to), and then again another choice in 6 months. Just decide on HIP 76 now and make one more decision right after the migration when all the attention is on it.

hashc0de
Before this HIP goes to vote, I'd propose one more change if @ferebee and others agree. Change minimum stake period to 1 month after veHNT is live on Solana. Specifically, it addresses a few gaps. Today, all existing staked validators would transition over to a "minimum stake period" when moved to veHNT Solana. HIP 76 sort of makes this minimum 0 days because the curve goes all the way down to 0 days. It also mentions 6 months explicitly but I'd like this to be way more clear. For those who were expecting a 3 month cooldown (125k blocks) this bumps it up to 6 months right at the transition. Now that I look back on this, I wonder if this was fair. Alternatively making it a 1 day or 1 week period encourages the wrong incentives. So I think it should be higher. I think 1 month is a happy medium. It also helps that we're about a month away from the migration so if we started voting today, they can still choose to enter cooldown (if they choose to) fairly quickly after the migration completes. Also the land rush period allows anyone to extend it longer if they choose. Putting all these decisions in the near term seem better than having to make one choice today (HIP 76 voting), one more choice at migration (land rush or not), one choice sometime in the interim (what subdao to delegate to), and then again another choice in 6 months. ferebee 02/27/2023 12:53 PM
I think that’s reasonable. I expect most veHNT will come from participants who choose to lock HNT for 48 months. The way the landrush provision is written, anybody considering locking HNT for a long duration will want to do so within the first week. Therefore, a 1-month rollover period should be more than long enough to prevent total veHNT from dipping to a dangerously low level at any time that proper governance would be in danger.
groot 02/27/2023 12:54 PM
How is the 3 month cooldown bumped to 6 months when this HIP makes the 'minimum stake period' 0 days?
12:55
If the 'minimum stake period' is 0 days then it actually unlocks all the validators immediately upon transition to Solana?
groot
How is the 3 month cooldown bumped to 6 months when this HIP makes the 'minimum stake period' 0 days?
ferebee 02/27/2023 12:55 PM
That’s actually a bit ambiguous. As written, HIP-76 states The 6-month lockup period specified in HIP-51 for validator stakes that have not completed cooldown at L1 transition will continue to apply. I agree with hashc0de that this should be specified more precisely. [Note: “HIP-51” was wrong and is being changed to HIP-70 in the current edit.] (edited)
ferebee

I agree with hashc0de that this should be specified more precisely. [Note: “HIP-51” was wrong and is being changed to HIP-70 in the current edit.] (edited)
ferebee 02/27/2023 12:57 PM
So let’s discuss here whether there are arguments against the 1-month lockup proposed by hashc0de. If not, I’ll modify HIP-76 to state that explicitly.
ferebee
That’s actually a bit ambiguous. As written, HIP-76 states The 6-month lockup period specified in HIP-51 for validator stakes that have not completed cooldown at L1 transition will continue to apply. ferebee 02/27/2023 12:59 PM
Right. Not properly made explicit. I was operating under the mistaken belief that HIP-70 etc. specified an explicit 6-month lockup for validator rollovers rather than a “minimum duration”. So, whatever the period is for validator rollovers, it should be made more clear. (edited)
Max - Just Max 02/27/2023 12:59 PM

Max - Just Max
Wait, you think most people will lock for 48 months?
ferebee 02/27/2023 12:59 PM
It makes the most sense to lock some for 48 months and leave the rest free, rather than lock more for a shorter period, because the optionality is greater.
Max - Just Max 02/27/2023 12:59 PM

ferebee
Right. Not properly made explicit. I was operating under the mistaken belief that HIP-70 etc. specified an explicit 6-month lockup for validator rollovers rather than a “minimum duration”. So, whatever the period is for validator rollovers, it should be made more clear. (edited)

Max - Just Max

ferebee 02/27/2023 1:01 PM
Of course it is. But not an insanely long time compared to Nova Labs runway and the expected timeframe for network buildout. I expect less HNT will be locked for 48 months than was staked to validators.
groot
nevertheless, the only reason it was 6 months in hip 51 is because that was the minimum which will now be gone. (edited)
ferebee 02/27/2023 1:03 PM
Correct and agreed. So therefore let’s just discuss what the correct length of time is. I need to state the actual period more clearly in any case, and will edit the draft accordingly. Valerie has put the vote on hold until those edits are made. I think the 1-month period suggested by hashc0de is a good idea, just like I think the 6-month minimum period was unnecessary. We just want to avoid a short period after transition when no HNT at all is locked, as then arbitrary attacks would become possible.
ferebee
Correct and agreed. So therefore let’s just discuss what the correct length of time is. I need to state the actual period more clearly in any case, and will edit the draft accordingly. Valerie has put the vote on hold until those edits are made. I think the 1-month period suggested by hashc0de is a good idea, just like I think the 6-month minimum period was unnecessary. We just want to avoid a short period after transition when no HNT at all is locked, as then arbitrary attacks would become possible.

ferebee 02/27/2023 1:05 PM
If zero HNT is locked, I can lock 1 HNT (or 100) and do whatever I want with DAO Utility Score, and also votes, as long as I can persuade Valerie to put my nutso attack HIP up to a vote. (Maybe I can send her a special kind of ice cream, and she will do whatever I ask.)
Siegfried
What are we talking about: validator stakes will automatically shift to a HNT lockup with 1 month duration (instead of 6) or everyone will need to lock up HNT for at least 1 month?
ferebee 02/27/2023 1:06 PM
Validator stakes, which are defined in HIP-51 to rollover to the “minimum lockup duration”, which is 6 months per HIP-51 and now will be zero, should, according to hashc0de’s proposal, roll over to a 1-month lockup. Everyone else can lock for any duration from 0 to 48 months.

ferebee 02/27/2023 1:13 PM
The 3x multiplier ends after the length of your lockup as set during the 1-week landrush period ends. (Regardless of whether you extend lockup later.) So you can lock for 2 weeks, then you get the 3x multiplier for two weeks. Good luc with that!

groot 02/27/2023 1:31 PM

hashc0de
we'll always need to strike the balance between long periods (incentive alignment) and short periods (potentially but not always more participation).
ferebee 02/27/2023 1:32 PM
IMO this particular point (validator rollover duration) is fairly unimportant. Important points are the long 48-month maximum with the linear curve, which makes short lockup durations quite uninteresting, and also the landrush provision, which provides a very strong incentive to lock right away for a long duration.
ferebee

Important points are the long 48-month maximum with the linear curve, which makes short lockup durations quite uninteresting, and also the landrush provision, which provides a very strong incentive to lock right away for a long duration.

groot 02/27/2023 1:53 PM
So @hashc0de, given that the HIP specifies 6 months and does not decrease the minimum lockup period for those rolling over, why do you consider it 'unfair' that those who aren't out of cooldown yet are rolled into a 6 month minimum? Wasn't that what was agreed all along and even created the shortened cooldown of 125k blocks in the first place?
ferebee 02/27/2023 1:53 PM
Look, everybody. hashc0de made two points. 1. I (ferebee) did not specify the intended lockup duration for validator stakes rolled over into HNT/veHNT lockups unambiguously. My intention with the current draft of HIP-76 was that it should be 6 months as specified originally in HIP-70. I need to edit the draft to make the duration unambiguous when reading HIP-70 and HIP-76 together. I think we can all agree on that. 2. How about we change the rollover from 6 months to 1. I hope we can all get behind number 1. I’d be editing right now if we weren’t arguing here. As for number 2, it sounds like people don’t like it. I really can’t find it in myself to get excited about it. How about a straw poll, or two. (edited)
hashc0de 02/27/2023 1:53 PM
i think the linear lock up curve adds a new wrinkle that needs to be resolved.

Max - Just Max 02/27/2023 2:17 PM

ferebee 02/27/2023 2:17 PM

gateholder

ferebee 02/27/2023 2:30 PM
Maybe I misunderstood your question. The current thinking is that the default, when you lock HNT, is that it is set to automatically prolong its lockup. So if you lock it at 30 days, it always stays locked at 30 days until you start cooldown. I think that’s called “continuous mode”. From what I’ve heard you can select cooldown right away, which is called “cliff mode”. These names will probably change.
ferebee
Maybe I misunderstood your question. The current thinking is that the default, when you lock HNT, is that it is set to automatically prolong its lockup. So if you lock it at 30 days, it always stays locked at 30 days until you start cooldown. I think that’s called “continuous mode”. From what I’ve heard you can select cooldown right away, which is called “cliff mode”. These names will probably change.

ferebee 02/27/2023 3:23 PM
Ah, of course. Custodial staking operators had to unstake anyway in order to avoid all sorts of complications.
ferebee 02/27/2023 3:45 PM
Validator rollover is defined in HIP-70, not HIP-51 In the discussion above, and in the last draft of HIP-76, I incorrectly stated that the 6-month rollover lockup duration of validator stakes was defined in HIP-51. That’s wrong—it’s defined in HIP-70. Because HIP-70 is the one that discusses how validators will be replaced by the Solana blockchain and veHNT. I have edited my comments here in the upscroll to reflect that. I’m correcting this in the current edit of HIP-76.
ferebee
I don’t understand the excitement TBH. Are people excited by the opportunity to unlock their rollover validator stake ASAP? To the extent that other people need to feel jealous about it? I’m not going to do anything different whether I get a 6-month or a 1-month rollover. I will extend some in landrush to 48 months, and let the other lie around doing whatever.
Another_AKA 02/27/2023 3:55 PM
A 1 month validator cool down might encourage some to spin up short term validators (knowing it is a 1 month lock) to grab IOT drop for validators--whatever value that is to them, that otherwise would not due to the 6mo cooldown.
Another_AKA
A 1 month validator cool down might encourage some to spin up short term validators (knowing it is a 1 month lock) to grab IOT drop for validators--whatever value that is to them, that otherwise would not due to the 6mo cooldown.
ferebee 02/27/2023 3:57 PM

Another_AKA

2
BigSkyTech 02/27/2023 4:11 PM
So I will only chime in here as an outside observer because I do operate several validators. I've based several decisions the last several months around the constrains that existed. That's my my cross to bear, I get it. I'm just saying that I agree with a statement made earlier by @Max - Just Max that the optics of this could be viewed as moving the goal posts. Again, I was going to stake them back anyway. Others maybe not so much. (edited)
hashc0de
Before this HIP goes to vote, I'd propose one more change if @ferebee and others agree. Change minimum stake period to 1 month after veHNT is live on Solana. Specifically, it addresses a few gaps. Today, all existing staked validators would transition over to a "minimum stake period" when moved to veHNT Solana. HIP 76 sort of makes this minimum 0 days because the curve goes all the way down to 0 days. It also mentions 6 months explicitly but I'd like this to be way more clear. For those who were expecting a 3 month cooldown (125k blocks) this bumps it up to 6 months right at the transition. Now that I look back on this, I wonder if this was fair. Alternatively making it a 1 day or 1 week period encourages the wrong incentives. So I think it should be higher. I think 1 month is a happy medium. It also helps that we're about a month away from the migration so if we started voting today, they can still choose to enter cooldown (if they choose to) fairly quickly after the migration completes. Also the land rush period allows anyone to extend it longer if they choose. Putting all these decisions in the near term seem better than having to make one choice today (HIP 76 voting), one more choice at migration (land rush or not), one choice sometime in the interim (what subdao to delegate to), and then again another choice in 6 months. Just decide on HIP 76 now and make one more decision right after the migration when all the attention is on it.
Tushar 02/27/2023 4:14 PM
I think most of the hnt in validators will probably be locked up for the max time during the land rush period anyway so I’d be supportive of this simplification. I don’t think there will be any large impacts and simplicity is better
Another_AKA
A 1 month validator cool down might encourage some to spin up short term validators (knowing it is a 1 month lock) to grab IOT drop for validators--whatever value that is to them, that otherwise would not due to the 6mo cooldown.
Tushar 02/27/2023 4:15 PM
This is a good point
16:16
Tbh I’m ok with leaving it at 6 months too. I don’t think this will make much of a difference to what happens
16:16
I don’t think there is a significant amount of locked HNT that wants to be unlocked in the near term
2
1

AndrewsMD 02/27/2023 8:47 PM
Voter fatigue is of little consequence in this scenario. What matters more is voter perceptions on what gets voted on and which HIPs get percolated to the top for voting.
Zwibbledibble42 02/27/2023 8:48 PM
A way I think about the 6 month lockup is a hedge against migration implementation hiccups as an exit justification. Not trying to throw stones at the dev team, you guys always impress. I just understand that these things are hard, so I’m expecting bugs (that I have every confidence will be dealt with quickly and professionally). Due to my confidence in Nova and the foundation, I won’t freak out if something doesn’t work 100% optimally day 1, or even month 1. Others may not be so accommodating. Keeping the 6 month lockup defends against a large amount of HNT coming unlocked during a period of network uncertainty. Again, deeply not trying to throw stones at the devs, they know far more about this than I do, but I can foresee a future where a significant enough slice of total staked HNT is under the control of people who see a bug and get spooked. Months ago we had to make a choice, stick with helium through the transition or get out. Anyone who made that decision should stick with it. So, If the goal is to increase the amount of staked HNT to avoid a negative market signal during transition (as is suggested by the 3x lockup period), wouldnt lowering the agreed upon unlock period be counterproductive to that goal?
1
20:49
Also I agree with the governance considerations and not moving goalposts etc
KeithR 02/27/2023 8:50 PM
Don't move the goalposts please. Validators had every opportunity to avoid the 6 month lock up post migration; if they didn't avoid it, then they don't care about it being 6 months.
AndrewsMD 02/27/2023 8:51 PM
Any HNT that gets locked up is a good thing in my opinion. Some will lock for shorter periods, others long term. I support any duration of lockup. Yes, even for just 24 hours. (edited)
hashc0de 02/27/2023 8:52 PM
ferebee did make his changes, fwiw. mostly clarifications. does not include any changes to the rollover lockup period. * PR: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/569 * Rendered: https://github.com/ferebee/HIP/blob/patch-2/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md
20:52
could be ready for a vote tomorrow if this conversation settles.
AndrewsMD 02/27/2023 8:56 PM
I just read the adjustment. It’s settled from my perspective.
Yuan 02/27/2023 11:04 PM
In my opinion, 1. The roll over cool down period Given that HIP 70 clearly stated the cool down period for validators is reduced from 250K to 120K blocks (roughly from 6 month to 3 month). It doesn't seem fair that before the migration the cooldown is 3 months, but after the migration, the cooldown will actually be extended to 6 months. So my recommendation is to change the roll over cool down to 3 months. It is a balanced choice taking into consideration of stability and flexibility. And I believe that was the original intention in the HIP 70 to reduce the cool down to 125k> 2. veToken decay function removal I do agree that removal of the decay function will reduce the cognition cost and execution complexity. But on the other hand, I also believe that the vote power should be aligned with your stake. Here is an example if we adopt HIP 76: Two voters, A staked 100 HNT for 1 year, today is the last day of cool down, A will have 2500 veHNT. B staked 100 HNT for 6 months, today is the first day of cool down, B will have 1250 veHNT. But IMO, B clearly has more stake than A, but less voting power than A in this case. So I believe in a way the decay function is useful for governance attack protection. The proposed changes has its merits and drawbacks, I am not against or for the proposal, just want to raise some discussions. edit/comment: my understanding is incorrect, please ignore. (edited)
Yuan
In my opinion, 1. The roll over cool down period Given that HIP 70 clearly stated the cool down period for validators is reduced from 250K to 120K blocks (roughly from 6 month to 3 month). groot 02/27/2023 11:11 PM
Would you reconsider 1) if the sole reason of the reduction from 250k to 125k blocks was specifically to avoid the 6 month lockup? The initial intention of HIP70 was to do nothing with the lockup, but because validator operators wanted the option to get out before the migration (for a variety of reasons, most vocal being staking pools) they got that opportunity with the full knowledge that if they didn't take it they would be locked up for 6 months. (edited)
1
hashc0de
i'd be open to adjusting my recommendation down to the 3 month value. my thinking is that less votes the better as we lead up to the migration. there's going to be a somewhat massive governance HIP coming (around all the "chain var" like parameters that need to be be set for the solana program launch). also a spin on one of neil's HIPs i've been thinking about. i'm a little concerned about voter fatigue as we get closer to the migration. (edited)
Siegfried 02/27/2023 11:22 PM
I wouldn't worry about 'voter fatigue'. I know other blockchain projects, that for quite some time had governance votes every day, without any problems. (Yes, the proposals were shorter). Voting doesn't take much effort, processing/discussing HIPs does. Splitting up HIPs doesn't lead to additional effort for voters, if the issues to be discussed don't increase. It can even lead to more structured and thus more focussed and slightly easier discussions. (edited)
Siegfried
I wouldn't worry about 'voter fatigue'. I know other blockchain projects, that for quite some time had governance votes every day, without any problems. (Yes, the proposals were shorter). Voting doesn't take much effort, processing/discussing HIPs does. Splitting up HIPs doesn't lead to additional effort for voters, if the issues to be discussed don't increase. It can even lead to more structured and thus more focussed and slightly easier discussions. (edited)
groot 02/27/2023 11:29 PM
I agree, and it potentially even decreases the workload as you can 'make up your mind' on individual issues without having to determine what other non-related items were changed this time.

AndrewsMD 02/27/2023 11:53 PM
BTW, I agree with @groot. This time limited accommodation of a faster cooldown was made primarily to ease the pain point of staking pools who wanted to return HNT to individuals prior to migration. This was perceived to be time sensitive in light of hopes that migration would occur by EOY 2022. Those who did not take advantage of the exception cooldown period accepted a lockup period of 6 months with a planned rollover of 6 months. Why change this to 3 months now??? Am I missing something? (edited)

groot 02/28/2023 12:02 AM
Funny thing is that the Foundation didn't want to waive the unlock period at all when HIP70 started. "It was known they had a 5 month (250k block) lockup when they went in". Then, after a lot of noise by validator staking pool operators they reluctantly agreed to the 125k block cool down. The arguments used then were mainly "they knew it going in", but those arguments somehow don't apply anymore... I don't have a strong opinion on the minimum lockup, I do have a strong opinion on this hypocrisy that we are apparently supposed to ignore.

Then, after a lot of noise by validator staking pool operators they reluctantly agreed to the 125k block cool down. The arguments used then were mainly "they knew it going in", but those arguments somehow don't apply anymore... I don't have a strong opinion on the minimum lockup, I do have a strong opinion on this hypocrisy that we are apparently supposed to ignore.
AndrewsMD 02/28/2023 12:20 AM
That’s a valid point. I was pleased however to see that in the end, they genuinely sought to ease the pain experienced by staking pool operators. Helium Rising provided salient rationale and I remember Capcom using political capital to provide a solution. With the land rush factor of 3x, coupled with the 100x carrot associated with a 48 month lockup period, I envision more HNT being staked post migration and for much longer than 6 months. The market will see evidence that the Helium community supports this Network of Networks.

groot 02/28/2023 12:38 AM

hashc0de 02/28/2023 12:42 AM
i remember the intentions of the initial 250k cooldown blocks (i was a part of those discussions years ago), the 125k reduction last year since it was a HIP i did co-write, and seen in practice what's been going on since its passing. for the most part, we did see many people kept their nodes staked even with macro effects shifting in the last few months.
00:42
so to answer your question, yes, context remembered.
00:42
the other thing i've been seeing is folks still coming in and misunderstanding the cooldown period and whether or not they can unstake. both in discord and in other channels.
00:44
and the last thing i've been seeing are more liquid staking and other staking products in the ecosystem. i'm pretty certain that regardless of cooldown duration, we will see liquid staking products built outside of this community regardless of whether or not some of the folks who have been around here for long enough want it. (edited)
00:44
it's just the reality of the market and of getting attention from the larger community in solana and beyond.
00:45
so back to the point of 1 month, 3 month, 6 month specifically for the staked HNT that's rolling over.
00:45
given that hip 76 (including the edits from the author today), will remove the cliff at 6 months and create a fully linear curve from 0 months to 48, i think it's reasonable to re-assess what happens to that particular group of stakeholders. (edited)
00:46
the thing that came to my mind (personally) was whether or not the assumptions are still the same given this new context.
hashc0de 02/28/2023 12:57 AM
one thing i'd hope for was to bring it to a vote but turns out even validators don't exercise that right too often even for HIP 70 where maybe 750 of them showed up?
hashc0de

AndrewsMD 02/28/2023 1:00 AM
As it stands today, validators are paid for locking up HNT for six months. When they enter cooldown, they are no longer paid and their tokens are released after 6 months. Correct? Why would this change because a barrier to entry, or cliff as you call it, was reduced to 1 HNT and 1 epoch? Existing validators were given an opportunity to unstake sooner on an exception basis, and those that didn’t, renewed their 6 month commitment to the project as a whole. I find the argument to reduce the staking period of existing validators lacking in sufficient rationale to support it. But remain open to better understanding differing viewpoints (edited)
hashc0de
one thing i'd hope for was to bring it to a vote but turns out even validators don't exercise that right too often even for HIP 70 where maybe 750 of them showed up?
AndrewsMD 02/28/2023 1:01 AM
People choose for a myriad of reasons to vote or not to vote. If it’s material enough, they will show up and vote.
hashc0de 02/28/2023 1:03 AM
When they enter cooldown, they are no longer paid and their tokens are released after 6 months. Correct?
Correct. The small but important addition I'll make is that after implementation of veHNT there's a new dynamic. Since veHNT positions still exist and are decaying, you can still vote with that position and delegate that position to subDAOs.
1
hashc0de
When they enter cooldown, they are no longer paid and their tokens are released after 6 months. Correct?
Correct. The small but important addition I'll make is that after implementation of veHNT there's a new dynamic. Since veHNT positions still exist and are decaying, you can still vote with that position and delegate that position to subDAOs.
AndrewsMD 02/28/2023 1:04 AM
We are on the same page with respect to this comment
hashc0de 02/28/2023 1:06 AM
i actually consider it a "feature". smaller stakes mean more participation, and decays mean that you're not penalized for "leaving" exactly. you've been aligned with the network likely for a while if you even thought of staking. (edited)

ferebee 02/28/2023 3:00 AM
Summary So we’ve had lots of discussion here on various points. Thank you all for participating. Some items have been contentious, in particular the concept that the clause extending the linear lockup curve to veIOT and veMOBILE is an improper overreach into subDAO governance. I don’t follow the argument, and the HIP will go to vote with that included, in the interest of simplifying the structure of the subDAOs at launch. We also saw a proposal to shorten the automatic lockup duration of validator stakes that are rolled over into locked HNT positions from 6 months to 3 or 1 month. I think that might be a good idea, but I also think it’s not important, and it can easily be decided in a separate HIP if necessary. Out of respect for the position taken by some that it would be “unfair” in some way, or “moving the goal posts”, I am not including it in this HIP. On all other points of HIP-76, I believe we have reached broad consensus. Let’s go!
03:00
03:02
Last orders please! HIP-76 will go to vote shortly. Any last comments? Speak now or forever hold your peace!
tchgeek 02/28/2023 3:38 AM
Let’s go vote ️
1
waveform 02/28/2023 3:41 AM
I would agree on the extending the linear lockup curve to veDNTs. We need something to lay an egg to start the chicken or egg which came first problem. Keep the 6 month lockup for validators, this vote is to fix a problem not create a new one. At about 3000 staked they will receive 1.125B veHNT and can put in a HIP afterwards to reduce the lock-up period. (If this can be done? Noah might hate me for this). New stalkers would need to lock-up the equivalent of 1.9M HNT for 48 months to stop a vote on this. And further thinking about this possible HIP. Any ex validator owner who extends their position should be invalidated from receiving any reduction from 6 months this possible HIP could offer. Stops people locking up for longer to vote on a HIP that then reduces their lockup period. And after further thinking about this possible lockup reduction HIP I hate it already. Lets just do HIPs to fix problems not create new ones to get to migration day ASAP.
waveform

New stalkers would need to lock-up the equivalent of 1.9M HNT for 48 months to stop a vote on this. And further thinking about this possible HIP. Any ex validator owner who extends their position should be invalidated from receiving any reduction from 6 months this possible HIP could offer. Stops people locking up for longer to vote on a HIP that then reduces their lockup period. And after further thinking about this possible lockup reduction HIP I hate it already. Lets just do HIPs to fix problems not create new ones to get to migration day ASAP.

gateholder 02/28/2023 6:49 AM
I do find communication lacking but not that there is none but rather slightly conflicting I recommend that people who are serious about hammering out the issues get together as a group whether that is physically or online but it needs to be a round table discussion I feel random points come up from different people that would be solved if we just got together as a group of concerned citizens of the helium network (edited)
AndrewsMD
As it stands today, validators are paid for locking up HNT for six months. When they enter cooldown, they are no longer paid and their tokens are released after 6 months. Correct? Why would this change because a barrier to entry, or cliff as you call it, was reduced to 1 HNT and 1 epoch? Existing validators were given an opportunity to unstake sooner on an exception basis, and those that didn’t, renewed their 6 month commitment to the project as a whole. I find the argument to reduce the staking period of existing validators lacking in sufficient rationale to support it. But remain open to better understanding differing viewpoints (edited)
gateholder 02/28/2023 6:53 AM
I never liked this position it was the main reason I sought out partial validation cood downs hurt the system IMO
groot
So, essentially, it is the change in curve that now has you wondering if it was fair to lock validators up that way for 6 months? I don't think it will matter though as I suspect many will stay in the ecosystem.
gateholder 02/28/2023 6:55 AM
To be frank validators were pretty screwed...
gateholder
To be frank validators were pretty screwed...
AndrewsMD 02/28/2023 11:50 AM
Strongly disagree. The only validators who had legitimate problems with the Solana migration mechanics were validator pool operators. Since they took possession of an individual’s HNT, it was prudent for a myriad of reasons for them to be able to put HNT possession back into peoples hands prior to migration. I have heard opinions that some wished that they were able to take advantage of the macroeconomic environment. And others feel financially estranged because they designed a business model around staking and now that model has changed. Screwed? No. Progression forward, . . Clearly. Hindsight is 20:20 for us all. However, validators were compensated for staking for 6 months plus the work that they did to keep the network functioning. Sure, they encountered expenses, etc, but no-body was screwed.
ferebee
Summary So we’ve had lots of discussion here on various points. Thank you all for participating. Some items have been contentious, in particular the concept that the clause extending the linear lockup curve to veIOT and veMOBILE is an improper overreach into subDAO governance. I don’t follow the argument, and the HIP will go to vote with that included, in the interest of simplifying the structure of the subDAOs at launch. We also saw a proposal to shorten the automatic lockup duration of validator stakes that are rolled over into locked HNT positions from 6 months to 3 or 1 month. I think that might be a good idea, but I also think it’s not important, and it can easily be decided in a separate HIP if necessary. Out of respect for the position taken by some that it would be “unfair” in some way, or “moving the goal posts”, I am not including it in this HIP. On all other points of HIP-76, I believe we have reached broad consensus. Let’s go!
Max - Just Max 02/28/2023 12:35 PM
Can we add a line explaining that the DNT change is being done because these subDAOs don’t have their voting mechanisms in place yet, however, this is not an expected power Helium DAO should have going forward
ferebee 02/28/2023 1:11 PM
No, for three reasons. 1. The reason we are doing this now is that the subDAOs don’t exist yet, not because their governance has not yet been established. 2. We have not achieved full consensus on this philosophical question, though I believe my position has the greater support, so it would be divisive to state 1. in the HIP. 3. This HIP is about the lockup curve and related matters, not about governance.
Max - Just Max

ferebee 02/28/2023 1:18 PM

Max - Just Max
Theoretically yes, but why would new subDAOs join if that’s the case
ferebee 02/28/2023 1:23 PM
What hypothetical subDAO would be dissuaded from joining because of the requirement that subDAO governance operate through voting using a veDNT? Boring decided against joining Helium as a subDAO because they preferred not to align their tokenomics with the Helium model. As we see from that example, there are advantages to requiring a subDAO to align itself fully with Helium tokenomics (and governance) models.
Max - Just Max 02/28/2023 1:24 PM

ferebee 02/28/2023 1:47 PM
Are you trying to be difficult? You proposed I add a line to HIP-76, and it hasn’t “apparently been denied”. I, the author of the HIP, stated, quite clearly, that I am not going to add that line. https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1075162020472697003/1080235871959269416 I also stated my reasons. Why are you putting up straw man arguments and knocking them down again, when we have discussed your position for hours already? The HIP process is very simple. Somebody writes a HIP (one person, multiple people). If it’s at all reasonable and coherent, Valerie, who is a joy to work with, will get it ready for a vote, and then we vote on it. Some people are for it, some against. If at least 2/3 of the HNT that participates in the vote is in favor, then it passes. After transition, we’ll do the same, except we count veHNT. Once the subDAOs exist, they will do the same, except we count veDNT, as specified in HIP-51. If you want to change Helium governance in some way, it’s a simple matter. You write a HIP, argue your position, and if a temperature check says it’s ready to be voted on, we vote on the HIP. Changing subDAO governance is a lot easier before the subDAOs are created, so you have 4 weeks from today. Yesterday, actually. If other people write HIPs, you can make suggestions, and the author will decide what to do about it. I got lots of good suggestions. Most of them I added to HIP-76, some I didn’t.

Max - Just Max

ferebee 02/28/2023 2:20 PM
I said I wasn’t going to get into this again, but I’ll break it down for you once more. 1. The subDAOs don’t exist yet. (If you think they do, well, sorry, you’ll have to argue that with a wall. I have nothing more to add.) 2. The subDAOs will come into existence based on HIPs such as HIP-51 and HIP-70. In various ways, later HIPs modify earlier HIPs. That’s an accepted process. Laws work that way too. 3. The bit you quoted in the screenshot actually doesn’t say anything about how subDAO governance works, except that it involves DNT and voting. BTW it doesn’t mention veDNT. That is introduced elsewhere in HIPs 51–53 and 70. 4. Until the moment subDAOs exist, HIPs are the proper way to specify how they will come into existence, and how they will work when they do. A newer HIP can override an older one. You can write all the HIPs you want now and put them up to vote before 27 March, and change subDAO governance every which way, if you get 2/3 of the HNT vote. 5. The temperature check currently has 17 thumbs up on “is HIP-76 ready to go to vote” and 0 thumbs down. You have been arguing this for days, but you have no consensus which would support starting the vote. If HIP-76 passes, you can still change everything back again any way you want with a new HIP, if you can gather consensus and get it passed. So go for it!
1
Max - Just Max 02/28/2023 2:26 PM
HIPs don’t need 2/3 of the HNT vote. You keep making up rules. I’ll get on writing those HIPs since time is a factor here they should be ready within 48 hours. We can use Thursday’s readiness committee meeting as the de facto community call and the IOT and MOBILE subDAO committees as the deciders of the voting mechanism for their respective HIPs. I’m sorry you chose to be difficult here.
ferebee 02/28/2023 2:31 PM
HIP-7 references https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rough_consensus whih says about “rough consensus”: It has been defined as the "dominant view" of a group as determined by its chairperson. Not sure who the chairperson is here, but recent HIPs have been decided by a 2/3 vote based on voting HNT via helium.vote, and I don’t recall anybody challenging that. There might be a need at some point for a more precise specification of the governance process. I’ll be glad to vote on your HIP for that. None of this is relevant to HIP-76 though.
Rough consensus
Rough consensus is a term used in consensus decision-making to indicate the "sense of the group" concerning a particular matter under consideration. It has been defined as the "dominant view" of a group as determined by its chairperson. The term was first used by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) in describing its procedures for worki...
1
