ferebee 02/28/2023 2:45 PM
Note that HIP-76 doesn’t make any statement on what veMOBILE and veIOT are good for. They will exist, as specified in other HIPs. HIP-76 ony takes a position on how much of them there will be under what circumstances. Thus, if it turns out that the subDAOs don’t use veDNT for governance after all, HIP-76 does not oppose that. I won’t get into how the mechanics of subDAO governance might be changed from what has been specified by existing HIPs. That’s not my focus here.
Max - Just Max 02/28/2023 2:52 PM

groot 02/28/2023 2:53 PM
rough consensus as described in hip 7 follows the ietf definition: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rough_consensus. 51% is explicitly not rough consensus

ferebee 02/28/2023 3:20 PM
As far as I can understand, your concerns relate to matters of subDAO governance. HIP-76 is not intended to determine how subDAOs will be governed, and does not take a position on whether governance mechanisms have already been determined by existing HIPs. The only intent is to modify the mechanism in which veDNT will be associated with DNT lockup positions. The lockup curves of veIOT and veMOBILE have been specified, and HIP-76 proposes to modify them. I suggest that you write separate HIPs that propose mechanisms of subDAO governance in greater detail. You can also propose methods of voting on those HIPs, perhaps taking into account the fact that they do not affect all holders of HNT equally. Again, it’s probably best to get all that done before transition, while modifying subDAO governance is quite properly a matter of Helium DAO governance. (edited)
Max - Just Max
It should be really quick. It’s mostly a carbon copy of this one breaking out the subDAOs similar to how 52 and 53 broke out subDAO specific pieces
ferebee 02/28/2023 3:26 PM
I think HIPs are probably open source, so you’re welcome to use HIP-76 as a template for whatever you like. That doesn’t affect that I am proposing HIP-76 to the HIP Editors as ready to vote, with the traditional temperature check straw poll supporting that. I might mention that you’ve said several times you would write something. It is work, even if you use a template, so you might want to get started.
Fizzy 02/28/2023 3:27 PM
I would vote for a hip that had one more sentence that clarifies something... and I thought that's all Max wanted... so ima lolz if it really is a carbon copy.
ferebee 02/28/2023 3:29 PM
Oh, sure! If HIP-76 fails to pass, I’ll definitely vote for a modified version that adds something like that about the veDNTs. As I recall, I only put the veDNTs in there in the first place because Noah asked me to. It hadn’t occurred to me.

ferebee 02/28/2023 3:41 PM
As Max quoted above, not much has been said yet about the actual mechanics of subDAO governance. The quote in Max’ screenshot says that it involves voting and DNT. There’s lots of room for a HIP that goes into greater detail. That would be a discussion worth having.
1
Max - Just Max 02/28/2023 3:49 PM
“This HIP does not wish to opine on the governance powers that Helium DAO has over any subDAO. It has been proposed in a way to include veDNTs due to the time constraints and governance constraints at the time of its vote. A consensus was reached within the community that separate votes on multiple HIPs would yield the same result as this single HIP, and for that reason they were proposed as a single HIP due to the absence of realms” (edited)
15:49
Add that and we’re good

valerie 02/28/2023 3:58 PM
i think @ferebee 's point about we dont have the mechanics of the subdaos and helium dao totally explicit is very valid here - and we need to. in my view, there will always be a helium dao level of governance that can make sweeping decisions for the network protocols at large. Simply because there will likely need to be unilateral changes like that made (including the one presented in hip 76, for example). This doesnt mean that the heliumdao level should make decisions in contradiction to what the subdaos want, but i think its a question of domain and scope. if we have network wide, unilateral changes that every sundao likely needs to implement for continuity, ease of use, etc, then those proposals would fall into the domain of the highest level of governance. Again, we need to make this kind of stuff explicit and we dont have HIPs doing that yet (hint hint - opportunity to write a HIP!). As it relates to HIP 76, i dont see why we wouldnt make this change for the subdao tokens - why would they have unequal curves? if there a reason for unequal curves per each token then it makes sense for another hip, but i dont believe that would be the technical advice at this point.
Max - Just Max
And it’s objectively fucking stupid to have 2 HIPs at the same time for the same thing but I guess that the only option here.

ferebee 02/28/2023 4:38 PM
To answer that, in my view, we have a process. Ideas arise. Somebody decides to write a HIP about it. (It’s not like I had the brilliant idea all by myself to linearize the veHNT lockup curve. We’ve been discussing the whole thing for months here on Discord.) There is private discussion, public discussion. I probably wouldn’t recognize that first Google Docs draft at this point. At some point, the HIP is ready to be voted on. Then, people will vote, and we’ll see what comes of it, and if we can get 2/3 of the votes on helium.vote, the HIP passes. (Maybe there is some other way to vote? I’m not sure about that. A good discussion for a different venue.) But where do we get this idea that other people decide what the HIP author(s) put(s) in the HIP? Anybody can write a HIP! Go for it!

School grades, Failing is under 70%, if that the definition of 'avg', why is a 68% still not a "Well, you have a rough idea of the material, so you pass. Fizzy

But I do remember way back when helium.vote became a thing, the topic of what a 'rough consensus' was, was a topic that was brought up and talked about. That shouldn't have had to happen if what it was, was clearly defined in hip-7 from the git go. Why wasn't it? waveform 03/01/2023 2:11 AM
I believe the original discussion about consensus was 2:1 (so 66.7%), #hip-39-hnt-redenomination around the 1st of Oct 21 really got into discussing it and we ended up with "Rough consensus to pass this HIP is achieved when the 'For Redenomination' vote receives at least 66% of the vote.". Joey/Jamie can probably confirm specifically. I wonder what rough consensus would be for a 3 way vote. But that's a governance channel discussion.
waveform
I believe the original discussion about consensus was 2:1 (so 66.7%), #hip-39-hnt-redenomination around the 1st of Oct 21 really got into discussing it and we ended up with "Rough consensus to pass this HIP is achieved when the 'For Redenomination' vote receives at least 66% of the vote.". Joey/Jamie can probably confirm specifically. I wonder what rough consensus would be for a 3 way vote. But that's a governance channel discussion.
groot 03/01/2023 2:16 AM
rough consensus in a 3 way vote would still be some percentage > 52%, at least in the IETF definition. It's consensus after all, not pick the least bad one. (edited)
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 03/01/2023 3:18 AM
Isn't rough consensus the wrong phrase? I always thought it was a super majority (edited)
1
03:18
Eg 66%+ (edited)
groot 03/01/2023 3:29 AM
HIP7 states rough consensus with running code the way IETF uses it
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 03/01/2023 3:32 AM
heliumvotes always been super consensus afaik (edited)
1
groot 03/01/2023 3:44 AM
Rough consensus with running code doesn't prescribe a % so you're free to use whatever. All it states is 51% isn't rough consensus and 99% is too strong. This IETF definition is used among engineers and their peers though, their goal is much more aligned, they're just bickering about the implementation.
03:44
heliumvotes has always used supermajority indeed.
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io
Isn't rough consensus the wrong phrase? I always thought it was a super majority (edited)
ferebee 03/01/2023 3:45 AM
HIP-7 defines Rough Consensus by reference to the Wikipedia article on the IETF process https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rough_consensus or basically, whatever the chairperson says is “rough consensus”.
ferebee
HIP-7 defines Rough Consensus by reference to the Wikipedia article on the IETF process https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rough_consensus or basically, whatever the chairperson says is “rough consensus”.
groot 03/01/2023 3:46 AM
They built the internet using it, so it must be good
ferebee 03/01/2023 6:16 AM
In other discussions, community members presented logically consistent arguments why the last draft of HIP-76 might be construed to impair subDAO governance. While I disagree with the premise on which these arguments are founded (that subDAOs currently exist), I think it’s worthwhile to take them into account, as HIP-76 does not intend to decide any matters of governance. Therefore, I’ve submitted another PR, intended to remove these concerns. The PR is here: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/572/files
avoid appearance of governance overreach by ferebee · Pull Request ...
1
06:16
@Max - Just Max have a look, maybe this works for you.
ferebee
@Max - Just Max have a look, maybe this works for you.

Siegfried 03/03/2023 2:40 AM
Throwing in another thought: People who lock-up for 48 months, while getting the same amount of veHNT per HNT, will have a non-negligibly smaller percentage of all veHNT and thus of veHNT delegation rewards. But it would be very shortsighted to take this as a reason to vote no, as the HIP makes many improvements that will overall be very advantageous for the ecosystem (and for any veHNT holder). (edited)
waveform pinned a message to this channel. 03/03/2023 2:43 AM
Siegfried
Throwing in another thought: People who lock-up for 48 months, while getting the same amount of veHNT per HNT, will have a non-negligibly smaller percentage of all veHNT and thus of veHNT delegation rewards. But it would be very shortsighted to take this as a reason to vote no, as the HIP makes many improvements that will overall be very advantageous for the ecosystem (and for any veHNT holder). (edited)
AndrewsMD 03/03/2023 3:59 AM
Another downside, . . . voting whales would have to lockup more HNT for a longer duration to maintain a similar level of voting influence.
Siegfried
Maybe someone who hasn't realized yet that Max retracted his call-to-vote-no Tweet on Twitter. (edited)
AndrewsMD 03/03/2023 4:12 AM
I have difficulty believing that one disgruntled tweet can alter the direction that Helium takes. If this were true, any social media influencer could hold a HIP hostage. We saw that attempt with HIP70 voting and we saw how that worked out. If it doesn’t pass, it’s because influential voting blocks don’t want it to pass.
EngineerAiTool 03/03/2023 4:32 AM
Per this hip, during the 7-day landrush period, anyone, including Validators will be able to increase the lockup duration up to 48 months?
groot 03/03/2023 4:33 AM
How I understood it is that doesn't change and remains a possibility, with or without this HIP, yes.
2
AndrewsMD 03/03/2023 4:35 AM
This is my understanding as well.
1
AndrewsMD
I have difficulty believing that one disgruntled tweet can alter the direction that Helium takes. If this were true, any social media influencer could hold a HIP hostage. We saw that attempt with HIP70 voting and we saw how that worked out. If it doesn’t pass, it’s because influential voting blocks don’t want it to pass.
Siegfried 03/03/2023 4:43 AM
If this were true, any social media influencer could hold a HIP hostage.
That's seems to be an overgeneralization. The likelihood that influential individual views may have significant influence increases the lower voting participation is, the more unequal voting power is distributed, and the more holders of very big voting power positions may be convinced/influenced. But as a general conclusion: disagree. (edited)
AndrewsMD 03/03/2023 4:49 AM
We have validators who traditionally don’t bother to vote, and we have experienced a whale who tried to hijack HIP70 in favor of personal interests We will have to agree to disagree on this one:)
AndrewsMD
We have validators who traditionally don’t bother to vote, and we have experienced a whale who tried to hijack HIP70 in favor of personal interests We will have to agree to disagree on this one:)
Siegfried 03/03/2023 4:52 AM
Yes, we can leave it at that.
2
ferebee 03/03/2023 5:44 AM
Hi all! @ferebee here, HIP-76 author. I’m still out of town ATM after the Nova/1663/Foundation meetup in Berlin, so I’m not following everything until Monday. But feel free to tag me anytime with questions.

ferebee 03/03/2023 6:04 AM
The primary effects of HIP-76 are that short lockup durations get more veHNT, and lockups shorter than 6 months are possible. Note that active validator stakes still roll over to a 6-month lockup, that isn’t changing. Short lockups get small (or tiny) amounts of veHNT, and to get the maximum allocation, you still need to lock for 48 months. Check the graph in https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md#simplified-lockup-curve to see the details.
HIP/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md at main · helium/HIP
Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.
ferebee
The primary effects of HIP-76 are that short lockup durations get more veHNT, and lockups shorter than 6 months are possible. Note that active validator stakes still roll over to a 6-month lockup, that isn’t changing. Short lockups get small (or tiny) amounts of veHNT, and to get the maximum allocation, you still need to lock for 48 months. Check the graph in https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md#simplified-lockup-curve to see the details.
Metawatch 03/03/2023 7:06 AM
Pardon my ignorance- When HNT are locked in and veHNT is awarded based on the associate multiplier for time duration what is actually returned to the investor at the end of the lock in period ? Is it the original HNT invested or is it veHNT converted to HNT at a 1-1 ratio.
DigidyDOG 03/03/2023 7:10 AM

Metawatch 03/03/2023 7:17 AM
My comprehension of these multipliers is that it allows those large HNT holders to multiply their voting power which would otherwise be further degraded as more HNT is awarded going forward. This with the 3 time multiplier in the genesis period will provide ongoing majority voting power in the long term…or something like that..
Metawatch
Pardon my ignorance- When HNT are locked in and veHNT is awarded based on the associate multiplier for time duration what is actually returned to the investor at the end of the lock in period ? Is it the original HNT invested or is it veHNT converted to HNT at a 1-1 ratio.
ferebee 03/03/2023 7:25 AM
@DigidyDOG You always have the HNT, and it doesn’t change. It’s just locked to the wallet until the lockup fully decays. veHNT is a “coupon” (the terminology is still evolving) that you can employ for Helium DAO governance, and to delegate towards subDAOs, which increases that subDAO’s share of total HNT. If you activate cooldown on your lockup, the amount of veHNT slowly decays to zero until the original HNT is released to your wallet at the end of the lockup period. By delegating your veHNT to a subDAO token, you earn a share of the 6% of that subDAO’s token emissions. (So you can earn IOT or MOBILE.) That part is similar to the validator staking of today, but instead of needing 10,000 HNT to participate, you will be able to lock any amount, starting from a single HNT. So anybody can participate. (edited)
1
Metawatch
My comprehension of these multipliers is that it allows those large HNT holders to multiply their voting power which would otherwise be further degraded as more HNT is awarded going forward. This with the 3 time multiplier in the genesis period will provide ongoing majority voting power in the long term…or something like that..

ferebee
@DigidyDOG You always have the HNT, and it doesn’t change. It’s just locked to the wallet until the lockup fully decays. veHNT is a “coupon” (the terminology is still evolving) that you can employ for Helium DAO governance, and to delegate towards subDAOs, which increases that subDAO’s share of total HNT. If you activate cooldown on your lockup, the amount of veHNT slowly decays to zero until the original HNT is released to your wallet at the end of the lockup period. By delegating your veHNT to a subDAO token, you earn a share of the 6% of that subDAO’s token emissions. (So you can earn IOT or MOBILE.) That part is similar to the validator staking of today, but instead of needing 10,000 HNT to participate, you will be able to lock any amount, starting from a single HNT. So anybody can participate. (edited)

@DigidyDOG You always have the HNT, and it doesn’t change. It’s just locked to the wallet until the lockup fully decays. veHNT is a “coupon” (the terminology is still evolving) that you can employ for Helium DAO governance, and to delegate towards subDAOs, which increases that subDAO’s share of total HNT. If you activate cooldown on your lockup, the amount of veHNT slowly decays to zero until the original HNT is released to your wallet at the end of the lockup period. By delegating your veHNT to a subDAO token, you earn a share of the 6% of that subDAO’s token emissions. (So you can earn IOT or MOBILE.) That part is similar to the validator staking of today, but instead of needing 10,000 HNT to participate, you will be able to lock any amount, starting from a single HNT. So anybody can participate. DigidyDOG

ferebee 03/03/2023 7:32 AM
@Metawatch Not at all. Today, whales control the vote, if they decide to vote. (Large wallets, like Nova Labs, Multicoin Capital, a16z, Binance, have seldom voted so far, if at all.) Now, anybody can decide to lock HNT for 48 months, ideally right away at transition with a 3x multiplier, and get lots of veHNT voting power. If you do the math: lock 3,500 HNT at transition for 48 months, get 1M veHNT. A whale looking to make a fast buck, or an attacker, who locks for 2 weeks to do a hit and run, would need 1M HNT at 2-week lockup to get the same 1M veHNT. So of course a whale who locks for 48 months will have massive voting power. But they will also be locked for 48 months. So they will be totally invested in the success of HNT and Helium as a whole. Just like us.
07:34
Gotta lock long to get the power. Whether you have a little HNT or a lot. Wanna fight the power? Lock!
07:34

rawrmaan 03/03/2023 10:24 AM
In my view, this is the part that you aren't understanding. If someone locked for 1 week, they would get 0.5x veHNT, compared to someone locking for 6 months would get 12.5x. This would NOT create wild DAO Utility Score changes because the short term stakers would have almost no influence
10:25
Even if they had a lot of HNT to lock up short term, it would be a bad deal for them, because they will earn 25x less subDAO rewards per HNT compared to a 6 month staker
10:26
The 48 month stakers will set the "baseline" return for subDAO rewards per HNT, and anyone who stakes less than 48 months will get an inferior reward. 1 week would be so inferior, that you could do almost anything else with your HNT (deposit in a borrow/lend protocol, etc) to get a better reward than if you were to stake to a subDAO for 1 week
rawrmaan
In my view, this is the part that you aren't understanding. If someone locked for 1 week, they would get 0.5x veHNT, compared to someone locking for 6 months would get 12.5x. This would NOT create wild DAO Utility Score changes because the short term stakers would have almost no influence

ferebee 03/03/2023 10:38 AM
I’m having trouble following your thinking. But I have personally had a discussion which indicates an intent to lock > 1M HNT for 48 months. That would result in a position of 100M veHNT. I don’t know how they will delegate and vote, but I do know that they are, by definition, dedicated to the long-term success of the Helium network of networks. And this is just from one discussion, and I am not well-connected at all. There will be large, long-term lockups.
10:39
To outvote that 100M veHNT with a 1-week lockup, you would need 200M HNT.
rawrmaan 03/03/2023 10:39 AM

10:40

10:41
But I do think there could be a separate discussion around how much stake is allowed to move between subDAOs every x numbers of days. There can/should be limits in absolute % changes over a certain timeframe to increase stability and predictability of treasury backing. But that's out of the scope of this HIP

Why? Afaik there is a 7 day period between redelegating and that seems more than enough safeguard
rawrmaan 03/03/2023 10:43 AM
Is it 7 days? I thought it was 1 day--hard to track all of this stuff. I'm not making a strong argument for it. Hopefully we'll see that it won't be necessary
rawrmaan
Is it 7 days? I thought it was 1 day--hard to track all of this stuff. I'm not making a strong argument for it. Hopefully we'll see that it won't be necessary
groot 03/03/2023 10:44 AM

rawrmaan 03/03/2023 10:44 AM

groot 03/03/2023 10:44 AM
Regardless, since you’re at least giving up on 1 epoch of rewards it pays to not swap it around too much.
rawrmaan 03/03/2023 10:45 AM
Ah good point. And especially if we end up having liquid staking (which I'm sure will happen eventually), the delegation should be fairly balanced/automated anyway
groot 03/03/2023 10:45 AM
I don’t like the idea of abusing the circuit breakers to impose economic rules though, they should be about preventing exploits and not imposing tokenomics
rawrmaan 03/03/2023 10:46 AM
That's fair, I would agree with that. I was thinking of Solana's 20% max stake change per epoch, but I guess that is more about preventing attacks as well
groot 03/03/2023 10:46 AM

10:47
Solana’s max stake change is more reasonable because you can seriously cripple the network by removing 20% stake as the leader schedule is made 3 epochs in advance (edited)
10:48
Sorry @ferebee I’ll stop polluting your channel now
ferebee 03/03/2023 10:50 AM
AFAIK there is just a 1-epoch (= day) downtime between undelegating and redelegating, to avoid exploits relating to changing a delegation late in an epoch, or something like that. We lost the 1-week waiting period early on.
1
groot
Sorry @ferebee I’ll stop polluting your channel now
ferebee 03/03/2023 10:51 AM

ferebee
AFAIK there is just a 1-epoch (= day) downtime between undelegating and redelegating, to avoid exploits relating to changing a delegation late in an epoch, or something like that. We lost the 1-week waiting period early on.
groot 03/03/2023 10:52 AM

basically stake changes only happen on epoch boundaries

EdB-charlietango 03/03/2023 12:10 PM
This sounds like good organizational change management in line with Lean Software Development, valuing the opinion of the person doing the work. Ultimately, Sam slam dunked the answer. The foundation will code per the results of the vote. Participatory governance involves everyone being able to have a say and shape opinions. If they really wanted to, they could go anon and rip on either side of the vote…or say it’s a waste of time entirely and give all their insights as to why.

It's vote ... You can vote yes or no ... not all people that vote yes attempt the discussion. Not the one that vote no either. I want people to read it and vote, I don't care if they vote yes or no.
Siegfried 03/03/2023 12:13 PM
Thanks for engaging in the discussion. Trying to catch up on the back-scroll.
disk91.com
My problem is the role of veHNT in the $IoT and $Mobile valuation against HNT and the unstability it creates if you have no lockup period, I don't see the interest of offering a power of 1.5 in vote to someone that lock something for a week. That is my opinion . It will be good to me if the community vote yes. I've chosen to vote no. (edited)
Siegfried 03/03/2023 12:19 PM
If there is a minimum time that HNT needs to be locked up or not (or how long such a minimum lock-up duration would be) is a different question than how long one has to wait after delegating veHNT towards subDAOs before undelegation/redelegation is possible. If one wants to limit how quickly delegations to subDAO can change, one needs to make changes to how long has to wait after a delegation to be able to re-/undelegate.
Siegfried

If one wants to limit how quickly delegations to subDAO can change, one needs to make changes to how long has to wait after a delegation to be able to re-/undelegate.

mcharliem 03/03/2023 12:46 PM
Yeah, I think this is the single biggest disagreement in this whole discussion. Disk91 is estimating that something like 1% of HNT is going to get locked up long term with these rules, and a number of us think it’s going to be much, much higher. Personally, I’m pretty confident it’s going to be >10% in the first week, and 20% isn’t out of the question.

It sounds like you’re trying to correlate to undermining a previously approved implementation, which I think is a bit of a stretch but I can appreciate the perspective.

EngineerAiTool
Per this hip, during the 7-day landrush period, anyone, including Validators will be able to increase the lockup duration up to 48 months?
waveform 03/04/2023 12:16 PM
Anyone can increase their lockup duration at any time. But increasing it after the 7 day landrush wont extend the 3x multiplier end date.
1
1
groot
I'm confident in your connectedness on these issues so I'll rewrite it to 1 day in my mind. Makes sense actually, normally on Solana it is mark for undelegation, wait for epoch boundary, it becomes free, you can redelegate it and that will take effect on the next boundary so the result is 1 epoch you have nothing
waveform 03/04/2023 12:42 PM
From my conversations with Noah about this. You can only change things (lockup period, cooldown on or off, transfer/split) if you are undelegated, and while you are undelegated obviously you dont have any delegated income in that epoch. So an epoch starts, and if you undelegate in that epoch to do any of the above then obviously you will have no delegation earnings in that epoch, but once you have taken that action you can redelegate and start to collect income the next epoch. And the V in the SubDAO Utility score is only taken at the start of the next Epoch. Here's a thought based on this: No-one is going to earn any delegation earnings in the 1st epoch. As everyone is undelegated and needs to do all their veHNT splits, extends, cooldowns etc before delegating. Which means no-one gets any of that 6% of IOT or MOBILE - so it must be un emitted. Only in Epoch #2 will anyone get any income from delegation. Here's another thought. Anyone wanting to lockup for a day and set cooldown = on and then delegate for example. Needs to do this right before the end of an epoch. As if they do it in the first min they will cooldown to 0 before they enter the epoch where they can earn. (edited)
waveform
From my conversations with Noah about this. You can only change things (lockup period, cooldown on or off, transfer/split) if you are undelegated, and while you are undelegated obviously you dont have any delegated income in that epoch. So an epoch starts, and if you undelegate in that epoch to do any of the above then obviously you will have no delegation earnings in that epoch, but once you have taken that action you can redelegate and start to collect income the next epoch. And the V in the SubDAO Utility score is only taken at the start of the next Epoch. Here's a thought based on this: No-one is going to earn any delegation earnings in the 1st epoch. As everyone is undelegated and needs to do all their veHNT splits, extends, cooldowns etc before delegating. Which means no-one gets any of that 6% of IOT or MOBILE - so it must be un emitted. Only in Epoch #2 will anyone get any income from delegation. Here's another thought. Anyone wanting to lockup for a day and set cooldown = on and then delegate for example. Needs to do this right before the end of an epoch. As if they do it in the first min they will cooldown to 0 before they enter the epoch where they can earn. (edited)
gateholder 03/04/2023 3:05 PM
is there a way we can get some kind of preview or video of what that will look like and the process even just an If-> then chart of what the ui for this will look like and the options available at those times
ferebee 03/05/2023 12:22 AM
Well... It looks like an important contributor (or several) has flipped their vote!
1
ferebee 03/05/2023 12:34 AM
We continue to debate HIP-76 in this channel. It’s a complicated subject, and lots of people have questions, so feel free to tag me. Thank you everybody for giving this your careful consideration. Helium governance with the current voting system is an imperfect process, which will get a bit better with veHNT, but it’s the best we have. Anybody can change a vote until the last minute (just vote again—the last vote is counted), so every vote is important. (edited)
2
EdB-charlietango 03/05/2023 5:39 AM
Has someone addressed the possibility of front-running on shorter lockups? Especially related to votes?
EdB-charlietango
Has someone addressed the possibility of front-running on shorter lockups? Especially related to votes?
Siegfried 03/05/2023 6:25 AM
Can you elaborate your question, please? What do you mean by front-running in this context?
Siegfried
Can you elaborate your question, please? What do you mean by front-running in this context?
EdB-charlietango 03/05/2023 6:28 AM
Buy token up just to stake to vote… then using it the vote at a relatively minimum lockup. Then dump after lockup expires. A careful watcher could observe this and use arbitrage opportunities. The watcher doesn’t even have to be voting. (edited)
EdB-charlietango
Buy token up just to stake to vote… then using it the vote at a relatively minimum lockup. Then dump after lockup expires. A careful watcher could observe this and use arbitrage opportunities. The watcher doesn’t even have to be voting. (edited)
gateholder 03/05/2023 6:30 AM
well the people who do the land rush and for an extended time are going to have very high leverage (due to the multiplier) making it very hard to influence things I am not sure I follow the advantage of what your suggesting?
EdB-charlietango
Buy token up just to stake to vote… then using it the vote at a relatively minimum lockup. Then dump after lockup expires. A careful watcher could observe this and use arbitrage opportunities. The watcher doesn’t even have to be voting. (edited)
Siegfried 03/05/2023 6:32 AM
HNT locked for long-time yields a lot more veHNT per HNT than HNT that is locked up for short durations. I expect Voting power held by long-term holders to dwarf voting power by short term holders, even if the amount of HNT locked for longer-term is smaller than the amount that is locked short-term.
Siegfried
HNT locked for long-time yields a lot more veHNT per HNT than HNT that is locked up for short durations. I expect Voting power held by long-term holders to dwarf voting power by short term holders, even if the amount of HNT locked for longer-term is smaller than the amount that is locked short-term.
EdB-charlietango 03/05/2023 6:33 AM
The voting intent might possibly be irrelevant. Someone watching those lockups could be interested.
Siegfried 03/05/2023 6:34 AM
Extreme case example: 1 HNT locked up for one day yields: 100/1461 = roughly 0,0684 veHNT 1 HNT locked up for 48 months yields 1461*100/1461 = 100 veHNT, that's 1461 times more veHNT per HNT locked.
EdB-charlietango
The voting intent might possibly be irrelevant. Someone watching those lockups could be interested.
Siegfried 03/05/2023 6:36 AM
Wait, you are not wondering whether a vote could be swayed - but whether someone who believes that buys are made only to short term vote and sell afterwards could anticipate price action?
Siegfried
Wait, you are not wondering whether a vote could be swayed - but whether someone who believes that buys are made only to short term vote and sell afterwards could anticipate price action?
EdB-charlietango 03/05/2023 6:43 AM
Yes, the nefarious action to short sell and undermine the network.
Siegfried 03/05/2023 6:47 AM
1. Hasn't been discussed in this channel afaik. 2. An arbitrage strategy based on this would need to require many people to believe that they can sway a vote with short term token buy and short-duration lock-ups. Not likely, as short-term lock-ups likely will result in relatively small percentages of total veHNT voting power. Likelihood may increase, (a) the closer vote is (b) the smaller the participation in a vote. That is an interesting argument in keeping in mind when thinking about whether it is important to increase participation in votes / voting system. I expect with voting being essentially free on Solana (as opposed to be expensive today), that participation will increase. 3. Is a topic ("token price related") that may be against the allowed topics per the rules of this Discord. (edited)
06:49
4. Don't believe, short-term(!) price action will affect the network much. (edited)
EdB-charlietango 03/05/2023 6:50 AM
I personally have a lot of empathy for code that’s easier to write…big time. I just have some reservations around no minimum lockup. I believe as this is an economic HIP, then some of the rules have to be suspended and understanding that we’re speculating on potential effects of a HIP.
Siegfried 03/05/2023 6:52 AM
I think the key aspect that makes coding easier, is to use the same function for veHNT payout and decay (instead of using and implementing two different functions), not a minimum duration for lock-up.
Siegfried 03/05/2023 7:02 AM
Let's do a back of the envelope calculation: For this example, I define "circulating supply of HNT" as "HNT that is existing and not sitting in a subDAO treasury." (meaning: all HNT that can be locked-up or is locked-up for veHNT) Say circulating supply of HNT be y . If 10% of circulating HNT is locked up 48 months (never mind the landrush multiplier which will go away eventually), this would yield (y/10) x 100 = 10y veHNT. If 90% of circulating HNT is locked up for 1 month, this would yield (y times 9/10) x (30 days x 100/1461) = 1.85y veHNT. So, I am not worried that short term lock-ups may clearly dominate a vote. And hence, that there isn't much room that someone could base an arbitrage strategy on that. (Actually, I assume that the percentage available for short-term buys of HNT will be significantly less than 90% of circulating HNT supply.) (edited)
EdB-charlietango
Yes, the nefarious action to short sell and undermine the network.
ferebee 03/05/2023 2:08 PM
I thought about it for a bit and still don’t really understand your threat model. If somebody looking to make a quick buck sells HNT short, they aren’t really hurting governance. The most that can happen is that somebody with longer-term interests buys the tokens from the short sale, locks them up for governance, and then the stability of the network is helped, not hurt. Unless I’m missing something!
Adogg 03/05/2023 3:02 PM
Is that little disclaimer at the end of the summary is what changed everyone’s mind to okay?
Adogg
Is that little disclaimer at the end of the summary is what changed everyone’s mind to okay?
ferebee 03/05/2023 3:41 PM
No... Before the HIP went to vote, there was some lively discussion, with @Max - Just Max in particular, whether HIP-76 properly respects the boundaries between Helium DAO governance and governance in the subDAOs. I couldn’t really follow Max’ arguments, especially considering that HIP-76 was never intended to change the basic rules of DAO/subDAO governance, but after some further discussion elsewhere I wrote the last four paragraphs of the Summary section to make that clear. (The full edit history of the HIP since it was first submitted is visible on GitHub.) With that change, Max endorsed HIP-76 before voting began. I don’t know whether or how he has voted. I don’t think the HIP Editor (Valerie) would normally accept edits to a HIP that’s already being voted on, and no more edits have been made. So I imagine it’s the further discussions we have been having here on various points since voting started that has led to votes being changed. Thanks to everyone who has voiced concerns before or after voting. The more we debate the issues, the better-informed all decisions can be. I think it’s a good thing people can change their votes, because that way all choices can be based on the best information available.

ferebee 03/05/2023 5:00 PM

KeithR 03/05/2023 6:42 PM
How does one benefit from front-running a forthcoming lock-up expiration? The only thing you can expect is that they are going to sell; right? Certainly not a likely indicator of a long-term HODL position. Seems unlikely to be a 'buy more' indicator. Unfortunately for the front-runner it could just be an indicator of wanting the freedom to sell rather than actually intending to sell. So you gamble on it reflecting an intention to sell and sell into their expiration to use their sell pressure to get a larger discount? Seems like market makers and other sorts of traders have a much stronger position to front-run actual sell requests that negate any potential benefit of watching expiration dates of lock-ups.
KeithR

Certainly not a likely indicator of a long-term HODL position. Seems unlikely to be a 'buy more' indicator. Unfortunately for the front-runner it could just be an indicator of wanting the freedom to sell rather than actually intending to sell. So you gamble on it reflecting an intention to sell and sell into their expiration to use their sell pressure to get a larger discount? Seems like market makers and other sorts of traders have a much stronger position to front-run actual sell requests that negate any potential benefit of watching expiration dates of lock-ups.

KeithR 03/05/2023 7:09 PM
I like your Australian HIP example; passionate group, vital issues affecting them differently, potential for unfortunate conflict in goals between them and the US crowd. OK. So then they want to time it right via expiration date information. Buying more HNT for voting power with a short lock-up period won't work as @ferebee has outlined multiple times; the 36-month-and-above crowd has too much leverage due to bonus. So that encourages buying HNT AND a long lock-up; no problem there and it gives them more leverage. Your other option is to time the vote for the days after a large amount of HNT is expiring to reduce potential vote power being used against you. That likely fails because any one can easily get that small leverage back within a single epoch.
19:10

ferebee 03/06/2023 4:05 AM
Looking at HIP-76, I see that it doesn’t actually state that the lockup duration of a locked HNT position can’t be reduced. While that is implicit in the concept of “lockup” in the first place, I should have stated it explicitly for additional clarity. Perhaps @waveform can add that to the docs. (It holds equally pre and post HIP-76.) So, for the avoidance of doubt, you can never reduce the lockup duration of locked HNT under any circumstances.

AndrewsMD 03/06/2023 5:25 AM

But I also suspect that others were not moved by the wording change. Whether or not that’s what moved the needle to potentially pass this HIP, I don’t know. I can say that developers prefer as much simplicity as they can get to ensure a smooth transition and implement the subDAOs. Passing HIP76 helps in this regard.
KeithR

AndrewsMD 03/06/2023 7:36 AM
No conspiracy my friend. No gaming, . . . strategic, . . . maybe:) HIP51 introduced a measure to ensure that those who vote do so in the best long term interests of the network. When Tushar first pushed this idea in HIP41, I errantly disagreed with it and thought it was simply a means for the whales to maintain control. I have since changed my mind and have seen how important this can be with real life examples. In HIP70, the existing job of validators will go away. What’s the value add for validators to continue to stake? Ans: A 3x multiplier land rush for a piece of the 6% subDAO emissions pie, plus a 100x bonus for long term lockup. There is much FUD going around with crypto in general. The Silvergate crisis adds to this.
07:36
It’s imperative that the market doesn’t view the implementation of HIP70 ad a loss of faith by the community through massive unstaking. The market must see that the Helium community still has faith in the project. “Look at how much staking grew after migration. . . not just 6 months, but for 4 years! This community is rock solid supportive!” If I were a founding whale and wanted to be strategic, I would consider growing my staking from 10% to 25%, such that the net aggregate staking amount grew. And if I wanted to be stealthy about it, I would wait until day 6, then stake whatever % of my bag that I needed (up to 25%) so that the net amount of long term staking increased by a significant amount :). Waiting until day 6 may just reduce the % of my bag from 25% to 19% OTOH, I might say to heck with strategy. I’m in it long term so I will just lead the way, stake early, stake big, and hopefully dispel community rug pull fears.

I was just simply asking originally if that last paragraph is what changed a lot of Hnt’s mind lol so to speak?

jimmybean
Can someone explain: removal of 6mo lock-up excluding validators? So those that are staking validators (ie 10k hnt) will still have a 6mo cooldown? Will validators receive a higher yield than other vehnt that is locked in return for their 6mo cooldown?
waveform 03/06/2023 2:27 PM
This HIP does not change that validators that migrate over will still have a lockup for at least 6 months. And it does not give them any additional benefits for doing so over any other veHNT staked in the first 7 days. Also see https://discordapp.com/channels/404106811252408320/857353417739730954/1081700440590262373
jimmybean 03/06/2023 2:47 PM

Separately, can you clarify that validators will not receive hnt, and instead will need to be delegated to either iot or mobile? I imagine many validators will prefer to get hnt. jimmybean
Thanks. What do you mean “never get hnt back until…”? What if a the hnt of a validator is custodied within one’s own helium wallet? Separately, can you clarify that validators will not receive hnt, and instead will need to be delegated to either iot or mobile? I imagine many validators will prefer to get hnt. Will that be that possible?
AndrewsMD 03/06/2023 3:50 PM
Going forward, no one will earn HNT directly except the initial investors. I think they get ~30%. Everyone else will earn subDAO tokens directly. This includes former validators, and anyone who stakes HNT or contributes to a subDAO network. They can however, redeem their subDAO tokens through the treasury for HNT or sell/trade it in an exchange . (edited)
15:54
I think Waveform’s comment about never getting back HNT should be interpreted as, . . . A validator will not be able to unlock their HNT, until they select cooldown. Thus, one could theoretically have a perpetual “X” month staking period if they chose. (edited)
AndrewsMD
Going forward, no one will earn HNT directly except the initial investors. I think they get ~30%. Everyone else will earn subDAO tokens directly. This includes former validators, and anyone who stakes HNT or contributes to a subDAO network. They can however, redeem their subDAO tokens through the treasury for HNT or sell/trade it in an exchange . (edited)
ferebee 03/06/2023 5:33 PM
HST holders currently receive 32% of HNT emissions, as you can see by looking up https://api.helium.io/v1/vars/securities_percent. That doesn’t change with the transition to Solana. The percentage decreases by 1% each year down to 15%, where it will stay.

VolkyEva 03/07/2023 1:48 AM
Guys i’m confused about staking if i locked it for 48 months i would recieve 100x what i locked?
01:49
After 48 months
groot 03/07/2023 1:53 AM
You get 100x the amount in veHNT (vote escrow HNT), but when that unlocks you just get the original HNT back, not 100x
VolkyEva
Guys i’m confused about staking if i locked it for 48 months i would recieve 100x what i locked?
ferebee 03/07/2023 2:05 AM
veHNT is like the amount of applause you’re getting when riding a tall unicycle. The taller it is, the more applause. As the HNT lockup decays once you begin cooldown, the unicycle shortens and the applause dies down, until you finally get off again.
1
1
2
1
ferebee
veHNT is like the amount of applause you’re getting when riding a tall unicycle. The taller it is, the more applause. As the HNT lockup decays once you begin cooldown, the unicycle shortens and the applause dies down, until you finally get off again.
VolkyEva 03/07/2023 2:23 AM
well thought metaphore
groot
You get 100x the amount in veHNT (vote escrow HNT), but when that unlocks you just get the original HNT back, not 100x
Dawgnuts 03/07/2023 7:41 AM
Has that always been the case with 51? VeHNT is strictly for voting power and there’s no gain in HNT at the end of a locked period?
1
Dawgnuts
Has that always been the case with 51? VeHNT is strictly for voting power and there’s no gain in HNT at the end of a locked period?
ferebee 03/07/2023 8:30 AM
Absolutely, throughout all of HIPs 52, 53, 70. HIP-76 changes details, such as the amount of veHNT assigned to 6-month lockups (12.5x instead of 1x), and it removes the 6-month staking minimum, but it doesn’t change fundamental parameters such as the maximum veHNT (100x at 48 months) or the 6-month automatic lockup of validator stakes introduced in HIP-70. For a TL;DR on HIP-76, just read the Summary section. https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md#summary
1
ferebee
Absolutely, throughout all of HIPs 52, 53, 70. HIP-76 changes details, such as the amount of veHNT assigned to 6-month lockups (12.5x instead of 1x), and it removes the 6-month staking minimum, but it doesn’t change fundamental parameters such as the maximum veHNT (100x at 48 months) or the 6-month automatic lockup of validator stakes introduced in HIP-70. For a TL;DR on HIP-76, just read the Summary section. https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0076-linear-lockup-curve.md#summary
Dawgnuts 03/07/2023 8:33 AM
10-4 thanks for clarification. Can I ask one more dumb question… (edited)
Dawgnuts
10-4 thanks for clarification. Can I ask one more dumb question… (edited)
ferebee 03/07/2023 8:34 AM
Yessir that is my job here.
Dawgnuts 03/07/2023 8:35 AM
The more veHNT delgated towards whichever subdao plays a part in the redemption value to HNT from treasury right?
Dawgnuts
The more veHNT delgated towards whichever subdao plays a part in the redemption value to HNT from treasury right?
ferebee 03/07/2023 8:44 AM
Not directly.
08:46
The amount of veHNT delegated towards a subDAO determines its DAO Utility Score, along with the subDAO’s DC burn for data transfer and the number of hotspots times their onboarding fee. (Note the square and fourth roots here.)
1
08:46
08:47
See HIP-51. The amount of delegated veHNT is the most important factor, as it is multiplied in linearly, while only the square root of DC burn is counted.
08:48
All HNT emissions besides HST investor rewards (which are currently 32% and drop by 1% per year down to a permanent 15%) are distributed among subDAOs in proportion to their relative DAO Utility Scores.
08:51
That HNT lands in the subDAO treasuries. The IOT and MOBILE treasuries determine the exchange rate between DNT (IOT or MOBILE) and HNT on the simple principle: All the treasury HNT is worth all the existing subDAO token. Now consider the 50B MOBILE premine and the 5B IOT airdrop. Both exist at launch, while the subDAO treasuries will start at zero HNT. Therefore, the treasury floor price (in HNT) of both IOT and MOBILE will start at zero and rise gradually as HNT accumulates in the respective treasuries.
08:51
You can exchange DNT for HNT by burning it to the respective treasury. The DNT vanishes, and the treasury pays out HNT.
08:52
However, DNTs will presumably trade higher on secondary markets, so the exchange function of subDAO treasuries will probably not be used that much.
Dawgnuts 03/07/2023 9:25 AM
Thank you for the thorough explanation and clearing this up for me
1

groot
You get 100x the amount in veHNT (vote escrow HNT), but when that unlocks you just get the original HNT back, not 100x
Screwtape7 03/07/2023 5:19 PM
So if you just get back the original sum of HNT what reward do you get for locking up a bunch of HNT for 48 months when it unlocks?
Screwtape7
So if you just get back the original sum of HNT what reward do you get for locking up a bunch of HNT for 48 months when it unlocks?
ferebee 03/07/2023 5:41 PM
Two things. First, you can vote in Helium DAO governance, i. e., vote on HIPs. Your vote is weighted based on how much veHNT you put behind it. Second, you can delegate your veHNT towards a subDAO as I described above. https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1075162020472697003/1082705825040191568 Each subDAO assigns up to 6% of its total subDAO token emissions to reward delegations. So 6% of all IOT, and 6% of all MOBILE, are earmarked for that. When you delegate veHNT towards a subDAO, you receive a share of those rewards. So if you are responsible for 1% of all veHNT that is delegated towards 5G, then you will receive 1% of 6% of all MOBILE token emissions.
ferebee
Two things. First, you can vote in Helium DAO governance, i. e., vote on HIPs. Your vote is weighted based on how much veHNT you put behind it. Second, you can delegate your veHNT towards a subDAO as I described above. https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1075162020472697003/1082705825040191568 Each subDAO assigns up to 6% of its total subDAO token emissions to reward delegations. So 6% of all IOT, and 6% of all MOBILE, are earmarked for that. When you delegate veHNT towards a subDAO, you receive a share of those rewards. So if you are responsible for 1% of all veHNT that is delegated towards 5G, then you will receive 1% of 6% of all MOBILE token emissions.
Screwtape7 03/07/2023 5:50 PM
Wow thats super interesting and helpful to the network overall encouraging stashing of HNT to bolster market value
17:54
I'm sorry I don't understand all that maths. how does staking VEHNT improve the SubDAO utility score? for example does it mean the more VEHNT is staked in the IOT subDAO the more HNT is added to the IOT SubDAO treasury for distribution as IOT tokens ? (edited)
Screwtape7
I'm sorry I don't understand all that maths. how does staking VEHNT improve the SubDAO utility score? for example does it mean the more VEHNT is staked in the IOT subDAO the more HNT is added to the IOT SubDAO treasury for distribution as IOT tokens ? (edited)
gutentag 03/07/2023 9:02 PM
almost! using IOT as the example: the more veHNT delegated to the IOT subDAO, the more HNT is emitted to the IOT Treasury each epoch. As more HNT is emitted to the IOT treasury, fewer IOT are needed to exchange for those HNT tokens, and thus more DC can be acquired. A simplified example would be this - if there are 100 HNT in the IOT Treasury and 1,000 IOT in circulation, then 10 IOT must be used to exchange for 1 HNT - if there are 200 HNT in the IOT Treasury and 1,000 IOT in circulation, then 5 IOT must be used to exchange for 1 HNT (edited)
1
gutentag
almost! using IOT as the example: the more veHNT delegated to the IOT subDAO, the more HNT is emitted to the IOT Treasury each epoch. As more HNT is emitted to the IOT treasury, fewer IOT are needed to exchange for those HNT tokens, and thus more DC can be acquired. A simplified example would be this - if there are 100 HNT in the IOT Treasury and 1,000 IOT in circulation, then 10 IOT must be used to exchange for 1 HNT - if there are 200 HNT in the IOT Treasury and 1,000 IOT in circulation, then 5 IOT must be used to exchange for 1 HNT (edited)
Screwtape7 03/07/2023 9:05 PM
I see so it alters the rate of exchange favourably the more HNT is in the treasury i.e each IOT token is then worth more HNT - Thank you extremely helpful
1
Screwtape7
I'm sorry I don't understand all that maths. how does staking VEHNT improve the SubDAO utility score? for example does it mean the more VEHNT is staked in the IOT subDAO the more HNT is added to the IOT SubDAO treasury for distribution as IOT tokens ? (edited)
Siegfried 03/07/2023 11:16 PM
The "V" factor represents the amount of veHNT delegated to a subDAO (see formula posted by ferebee above, the number can never go lower than 1), so if an additional 1% of veHNT is delegated to a subDAO, its subDAO utility score increases by 1%. Mind that the distribution of HNT to subDAOs depends on the ratios of the respective subDAO utility scores. If e.g. all subDAO utility scores change at the same time by the same percentage, the distribution of HNT to the subDAOs does not change. (edited)
1
ferebee 03/08/2023 2:32 AM
Excellent answers by Sam and Siegfried. If you look carefully at the formula from HIP-41 https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1075162020472697003/1082705825040191568 you’ll see that the amount of veHNT delegated to a subDAO is the most important factor determining the share of HNT a subDAO gets. To get twice as much HNT, a subDAO needs to have twice as much veHNT delegated to it. (Actually that’s not quite correct, but approximately.) To get twice as much HNT, you need four times the DC burn. (Square root of 4 is 2.) To get twice as much HNT, you need sixteen times as many hotspots. (Fourth root of 16 is 2, because 2*2*2*2 = 16.) (edited)
Screwtape7
I'm sorry I don't understand all that maths. how does staking VEHNT improve the SubDAO utility score? for example does it mean the more VEHNT is staked in the IOT subDAO the more HNT is added to the IOT SubDAO treasury for distribution as IOT tokens ? (edited)
ferebee 03/08/2023 2:39 AM
Don’t feel bad if you find the math confusing. I studied mathematics, and was working with the formula yesterday, and suddenly panicked because I thought there was a terrible problem with the formula that would throw everything off with the transition to Solana. Turned out I had an error in my spreadsheet, and got confused about how square roots work. So ask away!
2
Jamesbond 03/08/2023 10:58 AM
How does hnt go into the mobile subdao treasury?
CockyRoostee 03/08/2023 12:40 PM
So what's your take for HNT being delegated to the $mobile treasury? I know when I looked at it mathematically I came to the conclusion of 28% +/- would have to look at my spreadsheet to see how I got there. The reason why I brought this up is the utility score is greatly effected by #of devices online. The effect is greatly reduced in the formula due to the SQRT to the 4th power. (edited)
Jamesbond
How does hnt go into the mobile subdao treasury?
Siegfried 03/08/2023 12:42 PM
Every epoch (epoch is a period of time after which rewards are paid out, after the transition to Solana 1 epoch will be 24 hours), a specific amount of HNT will be created. This HNT will be instantly distributed to all existing and working subDAO treasuries and "investors" (=wallets that hold Helium Security Tokens). The share for HST holders is constant each year, the share going to the different subDAOs is determined each epoch anew, depending on (1) how much veHNT is delegated to what subDAO, (b) value of DC spent to pay for services of the subDAO and (c) amount of (active devices * onboarding fees they each paid). (edited)
12:43
The calculated amount of HNT due will appear in the subDAO treasury.
CockyRoostee
So what's your take for HNT being delegated to the $mobile treasury? I know when I looked at it mathematically I came to the conclusion of 28% +/- would have to look at my spreadsheet to see how I got there. The reason why I brought this up is the utility score is greatly effected by #of devices online. The effect is greatly reduced in the formula due to the SQRT to the 4th power. (edited)
Siegfried 03/08/2023 12:45 PM
We delegate veHNT, not HNT. As to the percentages delegated: don't dare to make specific guesses, too many unknowns. I would be surprised if the amount delegated to IOT would be higher than the amount delegated to MOBILE, though. (Not saying it is impossible) (edited)
CockyRoostee
So what's your take for HNT being delegated to the $mobile treasury? I know when I looked at it mathematically I came to the conclusion of 28% +/- would have to look at my spreadsheet to see how I got there. The reason why I brought this up is the utility score is greatly effected by #of devices online. The effect is greatly reduced in the formula due to the SQRT to the 4th power. (edited)
Siegfried 03/08/2023 12:50 PM
The effect is greatly reduced in the formula due to the SQRT to the 4th power
I'd conclude that differences in activation fees paid by devices online (it's the fee amount, btw, not the amount of devices itself) between the subDAOs matter less than differences in DC spent or veHNT delegated. (edited)
Siegfried
Every epoch (epoch is a period of time after which rewards are paid out, after the transition to Solana 1 epoch will be 24 hours), a specific amount of HNT will be created. This HNT will be instantly distributed to all existing and working subDAO treasuries and "investors" (=wallets that hold Helium Security Tokens). The share for HST holders is constant each year, the share going to the different subDAOs is determined each epoch anew, depending on (1) how much veHNT is delegated to what subDAO, (b) value of DC spent to pay for services of the subDAO and (c) amount of (active devices * onboarding fees they each paid). (edited)

waveform 03/08/2023 1:39 PM
The Onboarding fee for an IOT only hotspot is $40 to the IOT subDAO, the Onboarding fee for a 5G/IOT hotpsot is $40 to the IOT subDAO. There currently is no Onboarding fee for the 5G part of a hotspot to count towards the DAO utility score. See conversation in https://discordapp.com/channels/404106811252408320/1030557618017673227
waveform

There currently is no Onboarding fee for the 5G part of a hotspot to count towards the DAO utility score. See conversation in https://discordapp.com/channels/404106811252408320/1030557618017673227

Siegfried 03/08/2023 11:43 PM
Until yesterday, I was completely unaware that devices pay/paid no onboarding fees to the MOBILE subDAO. I had wrongly assumed, device activation fees were of roughly equal amounts and the A term thus reflecting the number of devices onboarded and active. This isn't the case. https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1030557618017673227/1082812334604566570 I hope there will be a solution for this soon, as - at the moment - it breaks the idea that the A term in the subDAO utility score should somehow reflect the number/value of active devices on a subDAO. It also affects the HNT distribution strongly towards Lora for the time being. I need to rethink a few things here regarding my estimates on HNT distribution between the two subDAOs for the time being. (edited)
Adogg
I will say I am glad that ferebee did bring up the selling point made to the community over and over again about iot being over 90% to start, because that seems like pie in the sky now. If I am honest it kinda irks me, because I was one of the few that could see this coming from a mile away. A lot of us got shunned like we were making ridiculous opinions at the time. (edited)
ferebee 03/09/2023 4:11 AM
Expanding the Helium ecosystem from one network to many is one of those things Frank is referencing when he talks about the Helium airplane we’re all aboard, that we’re continually rebuilding while we are in the air. LoRa is the OG, and deserves the utmost respect for getting us off the ground at Kitty Hawk. Still, as with any startup enterprise, the goal is to grow the revenue. It will be years before LoRa revenue starts to grow in earnest. 5G has the potential for a much quicker ramp. It probably will be a while before we have 1M 5G hotspots, but the monthly 5G revenue might easily reach $1M while the LoRa revenue is still economically insignificant. But note how the Utility Score works. Only the square root of DC burn is counted. So if 5G is doing $1M revenue/month, and LoRa only $10K, 5G is bringing in 100x the revenue, a. k. a. money. The square root of 100 is 10. So in the D component, LoRa would get 10% of the credit for doing just 1% of the work. Meanwhile, the revenue brought in by 5G will benefit the entire ecosystem, and bring value to the HNT being earned by LoRa then, and also to the HNT LoRa earned in the past, when it was the pioneer.
Siegfried
Until yesterday, I was completely unaware that devices pay/paid no onboarding fees to the MOBILE subDAO. I had wrongly assumed, device activation fees were of roughly equal amounts and the A term thus reflecting the number of devices onboarded and active. This isn't the case. https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1030557618017673227/1082812334604566570 I hope there will be a solution for this soon, as - at the moment - it breaks the idea that the A term in the subDAO utility score should somehow reflect the number/value of active devices on a subDAO. It also affects the HNT distribution strongly towards Lora for the time being. I need to rethink a few things here regarding my estimates on HNT distribution between the two subDAOs for the time being. (edited)
waveform 03/09/2023 4:17 AM
You can see why I've been mentioning it for months now. We dont have defined for the MOBILE DAO Utility score A factor (1) What a device is, (2) What the onboarding $ for that device is and (3) what defines an active device.

ferebee
Expanding the Helium ecosystem from one network to many is one of those things Frank is referencing when he talks about the Helium airplane we’re all aboard, that we’re continually rebuilding while we are in the air. LoRa is the OG, and deserves the utmost respect for getting us off the ground at Kitty Hawk. Still, as with any startup enterprise, the goal is to grow the revenue. It will be years before LoRa revenue starts to grow in earnest. 5G has the potential for a much quicker ramp. It probably will be a while before we have 1M 5G hotspots, but the monthly 5G revenue might easily reach $1M while the LoRa revenue is still economically insignificant. But note how the Utility Score works. Only the square root of DC burn is counted. So if 5G is doing $1M revenue/month, and LoRa only $10K, 5G is bringing in 100x the revenue, a. k. a. money. The square root of 100 is 10. So in the D component, LoRa would get 10% of the credit for doing just 1% of the work. Meanwhile, the revenue brought in by 5G will benefit the entire ecosystem, and bring value to the HNT being earned by LoRa then, and also to the HNT LoRa earned in the past, when it was the pioneer.

Dust3317 04/03/2023 9:09 AM
@ferebee I just now read through HIP-76. Well done all of those who have contributed & especially @ferebee . Despite the very clear verbiage, I have a few questions that perhaps the community could answer. I currently have a validator which, based on the verbiage, will be automatically staked for 6 months after the rollover. Based on this point: 1. Let’s assume I elect to stake a position for 6 months leveraging all of these validator tokens. After 6 months, would I have immediate access to my HNT or would it then enter into “cooldown”? I am trying to understand if the minimum 6 month-post validator position is actually 6 months or if it is 6 months + a cooldown period. a. If there is a cooldown period, how much time would that be? i. If all of the above would be true (ie 6 months + cooldown), what is the “all-in” time required until I could access HNT from my original Validator position? 2. Let’s assume that at the end of the 6 months I decide to extend my position longer. How is this executed and are there any bonuses or incentives (like the landrush bonus) for doing so? Lastly, does anyone know if Gristleking has done a new video on all of this information yet? Thanks!
Dust3317

If there is a cooldown period, how much time would that be? i. Lastly, does anyone know if Gristleking has done a new video on all of this information yet? Thanks!

ferebee 04/03/2023 9:36 AM
“6 months” means 6 months. A position locked for a six-month duration is inaccessible (can’t be transferred, or burned to DC) for 6 months. Terminology is unfortunately confusing at the moment. The Helium lockup mechanism will use Realms, a standard Solana system for such things. In Realms terminology, you can select “Cliff” or “Continuous” mode.
09:36
. More familiar terms might be “Cooldown” and “Auto-Prolong” modes. In the first, the lockup decays, so if you start out with a six-month lockup, two months later it will be locked for a remainder of four months. The veHNT multiplier decays with the duration, so if you start with 6 months (12.5x veHNT multiplier), two months later you will have an 8.3x multiplier. If you choose “Continuous” (or “Auto-Prolong” or whatever it will be called in the end), then the 6-month lockup keeps getting prolonged, so the duration and therefore the multiplier always stay at 6 months and 12.5x. You can switch modes at any time back and forth with no penalty. You can also increase the lockup duration at any time up to the maximum.
Dust3317
@ferebee I just now read through HIP-76. Well done all of those who have contributed & especially @ferebee . Despite the very clear verbiage, I have a few questions that perhaps the community could answer. I currently have a validator which, based on the verbiage, will be automatically staked for 6 months after the rollover. Based on this point: 1. Let’s assume I elect to stake a position for 6 months leveraging all of these validator tokens. After 6 months, would I have immediate access to my HNT or would it then enter into “cooldown”? I am trying to understand if the minimum 6 month-post validator position is actually 6 months or if it is 6 months + a cooldown period. a. If there is a cooldown period, how much time would that be? i. If all of the above would be true (ie 6 months + cooldown), what is the “all-in” time required until I could access HNT from my original Validator position? 2. Let’s assume that at the end of the 6 months I decide to extend my position longer. How is this executed and are there any bonuses or incentives (like the landrush bonus) for doing so? Lastly, does anyone know if Gristleking has done a new video on all of this information yet? Thanks!
waveform 04/03/2023 10:23 AM
6 months will be 183 day long epochs When you select cooldown, it will be 183 days before you get your HNT back. If you dont select cooldown for 2 weeks then the 183 days starts 2 weeks later.
1
